{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox song | name = 99 Luftballons | cover = 99 Luftballons single cover.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Nena (band)|Nena]] | album = [[Nena (album)|Nena]] ''and'' [[99 Luftballons (album)|99 Luftballons]] | released = {{unbulleted list|1983 {{small|(West Germany)}}|1984 {{small|(United Kingdom)}}}} | format = {{hlist|[[7-inch single]]|[[12-inch single]]}} | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Neue Deutsche Welle]] | length = 3:53 | label = [[Epic Records|Epic]] | writer = {{unbulleted list|[[Jörn-Uwe Fahrenkrog-Petersen|Uwe Fahrenkrog-Petersen]] {{small|(music)}}|[[Carlo Karges]] {{small|(German lyrics)}}|[[Kevin McAlea]] {{small|(English lyrics)}}}} | producer = | prev_title = [[Nena (album)#"Nur geträumt"|Nur geträumt]] | prev_year = 1982 | next_title = [[Nena (album)#"Leuchtturm"|Leuchtturm]] | next_year = 1983 | misc = {{Extra music sample|Type=single|filename=Nena-luftballons-livever-clip.ogg|format=[[Ogg]]|title=99 Luftballons}} {{External music video|{{YouTube|La4Dcd1aUcE|"99 Luftballons"}}}} }} "'''99 Luftballons'''" ({{lang-de|Neunundneunzig Luftballons}}, "99 balloons") is a song by the German band [[Nena (band)|Nena]] from their 1983 [[Nena (album)|self-titled album]]. An English-language version titled "'''99 Red Balloons'''", with lyrics by [[Kevin McAlea]], was also released on the album ''[[99 Luftballons (album)|99 Luftballons]]'' in 1984 after widespread success of the original in Europe and Japan. The English version is not a [[direct translation]] of the German original and contains somewhat different lyrics.{{cite web|title= 99 Red Balloons – interview with the writer, Kevin McAlea |publisher= Eighty-eightynine |url= http://www.eightyeightynine.com/music/99luftballoons-english.html |accessdate= 17 July 2014}} ==Lyrics== While at a [[The Rolling Stones European Tour 1982|June 1982 concert]] by [[the Rolling Stones]] in [[West Berlin]], Nena's guitarist [[Carlo Karges]] noticed that balloons were being released. As he watched them move toward the horizon, he noticed them shifting and changing shapes, where they looked like strange [[spacecraft]] (referred to in the German lyrics as a "[[Unidentified flying object|UFO]]"). He thought about what might happen if they floated over the [[Berlin Wall]] to the [[East Berlin|Soviet sector]].''[[Rolling Stone]]'', 15 March 1984 Also cited by the band was a newspaper article from the ''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'' about five local high school students in 1973 who played a prank to simulate a UFO by launching 99 (one was lost from the original 100) aluminized Mylar balloons attached with ribbons to a traffic flare. The red flame from the flare reflected by the balloons gave the appearance of a large pulsating red object floating over [[Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area|Red Rock Canyon]] outside the [[Las Vegas Valley]] in Nevada.{{cite news|title= Strange flying object sighted over Red Rock |date= 9 September 1973 |newspaper= [[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]}} A direct translation of the title is sometimes given as "Ninety-Nine Air Balloons", but the song became known in English as "Ninety-Nine Red Balloons".{{cite web|title= The New English-German Dictionary: "Luftballon" |accessdate= 2 June 2007 |url= http://www.iee.et.tu-dresden.de/cgi-bin/cgiwrap/wernerr/search.sh?string=luftballon&nocase=on&hits=50 |quote= ''balloon -- der Luftballon''}} {{dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|title= The New English-German Dictionary: "Balloon" |accessdate= 2 June 2007 |url= http://www.iee.et.tu-dresden.de/cgi-bin/cgiwrap/wernerr/search.sh?string=balloon&nocase=on&hits=50 |quote= ''balloon -- der Ballon, balloon -- der Luftballon''}} {{dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The title "99 Red Balloons" almost [[scansion|scans]] correctly with the syllables falling in the right places within the rhythm of the first line of lyrics, although ''Neunundneunzig'' (99) has one syllable more than "ninety-nine". The lyrics of the original German version tell a story: 99 balloons are mistaken for UFOs, causing a [[General officer|general]] to send pilots to investigate. Finding nothing but children's balloons, the pilots decide to put on a show and shoot them down. The display of force worries the nations along the borders and the [[defence minister]]s on each side bang the drums of conflict to grab power for themselves. In the end, a 99-year war results from the otherwise harmless flight of balloons, causing devastation on all sides without a victor. At the end, the singer walks through the devastated ruins and lets loose a balloon, watching it fly away.{{cite web|title= 99 Luftballons, Side by Side Comparison |website= In the 80s |accessdate= 29 October 2014|url= http://www.inthe80s.com/redger3.shtml}} ==English version and other re-recordings== The English version retains the spirit of the original narrative, but many of the lyrics are translated poetically rather than directly translated: red helium balloons are casually released by the civilian singer (narrator) with her unnamed friend into the sky and are registered as missiles by a faulty [[early warning system]]; the balloons are mistaken for military aircraft which results in panic and eventually nuclear war. From the outset Nena and other members of the band expressed disapproval for the English version of the song, "99 Red Balloons". In March 1984, the band's keyboardist and song co-writer [[Jörn-Uwe Fahrenkrog-Petersen|Uwe Fahrenkrog Petersen]] said, "We made a mistake there. I think the song loses something in translation and even sounds silly."{{cite magazine|title= A very good group from Germany |magazine= No.1 |date= 17 March 1984 |page= 38}} In another interview that month the band including Nena herself were quoted as being "not completely satisfied" with the English version since it was "too blatant" for a group not wishing to be seen as a protest band.{{cite magazine|first= Andy |last= Strike |title= 99 Red Herrings |magazine= [[Record Mirror]] |date= 10 March 1984 |page= 14}} Despite having given in excess of 500 concerts over a period of more than 30 years, Nena has never sung "99 Red Balloons" live, even at her rare concerts in England, always performing the German version instead.{{cite web|title= Nena tours and setlists |url= http://www.nena.de/gigografie |publisher= Nena.de |accessdate= 10 June 2015}}{{failed verification|date=June 2015}} There have been two re-recordings of the original German version of the song that have been released by Nena: a modern version in 2002, which was included on ''[[Nena feat. Nena]]'' (2002),{{cite web|title= Nena feat. Nena – 20 Jahre by Nena |url= https://itunes.apple.com/de/album/nena-feat.-nena-20-jahre/id79336560?l=en |publisher= [[iTunes]] DE. [[Apple Inc.]] |accessdate= 27 June 2013}} and a retro version in 2009,{{cite web|title= 99 Luftballons – Single by Nena |url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/99-luftballons-single/id587139487 |publisher= [[iTunes Store|iTunes]] US. [[Apple Inc.]] |accessdate= 27 June 2013}} which included some verses in French. Live recordings of the song are included on all seven of Nena's live albums, dating from 1995 to 2018.{{cite web|title= 99 Luftballons |url= http://www.nena.de/de/99-luftballons |website= Nena.de |accessdate= 8 March 2016}}{{cite web|title= Live at SO36 |url= http://www.nena.de/de/discografie/live-so36 |website= Nena.de |accessdate= 8 March 2016}}{{cite web|title= Nichts Versäumt Live |website= Nena.de |accessdate= 9 November 2018 |url= https://www.nena.de/en/node/2505}} A special edit that combined the English and German versions of the song was played on [[American Top 40]] with [[Casey Kasem]] for the week of 24 March 1984 (Program #814-12).{{cite book|first= Pete |last= Battistini |year= 2010 |title= American Top 40 with Casey Kasem (the 1980s) |publisher= AuthorHouse |page= 224 |isbn= 978-1-45205-038-6}} ==Reception== American and Australian audiences preferred the original German version, which became a very successful non-English-language song, topping charts in both countries, reaching {{nobr|No.{{space|hair}}1}} on the ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cash Box]]'' chart, [[Kent Music Report]], and {{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}2}} on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], behind "[[Jump (Van Halen song)|Jump]]" by [[Van Halen]].{{cite magazine|title= March 3, 1984 – The Hot 100 |url= http://www.billboard.com/charts/1984-03-03/hot-100 |magazine= [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date= 3 March 1984 |accessdate= 17 July 2014}} It was certified [[RIAA certification|Gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. The later-released English translation, "99 Red Balloons", topped the charts in the UK, Canada and Ireland. [[VH1 Classic]], an American cable television station, ran a charity event for [[Hurricane Katrina]] relief in 2006. Viewers who made donations were allowed to choose which [[music video]]s the station would play. One viewer donated $35,000 for the right to program an entire hour and requested continuous play of "99 Luftballons" and "99 Red Balloons" videos. The station broadcast the videos as requested from 2:00 to 3:00 pm [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] on 26 March 2006.{{cite press release|title= VH1 Classic to Air the Classic 80s Music Video '99 Luftballons' for an Entire Hour on Sunday, 26 March |date= 22 March 2006 |publisher= [[VH1 Classic]]. [[PR Newswire]] |accessdate= 28 March 2014 |url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/vh1-classic-to-air-the-classic-80s-music-video-99-luftballons-for-an-entire-hour-on-sunday-march-26-55496712.html}}{{cite news|title= VH1 Classic to air '99 Red Balloons' music video for a full hour |newspaper= [[USA Today]] |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= 24 March 2006 |accessdate= 11 October 2017 |url= https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2006-03-24-vh1-classic-fundraiser_x.htm}} In his 2010 book ''[[Music: What Happened?]]'', critic and musician [[Scott Miller (pop musician)|Scott Miller]] declared that the song possesses "one of the best [[Hook (music)|hook]]s of [[1980s in music|the eighties]]" and listed it among his top song picks for 1984. Nonetheless, he cautioned: "It must be admitted that this song suffers from an embarrassingly out-of-place disco funk interlude, and the word ''kriegsminister''."{{cite book|first= Scott |last= Miller |authorlink= Scott Miller (pop musician) |title= Music: What Happened? |year= 2010 |page= 120 |publisher= 125 Books |location= Alameda, CA |isbn= 978-0-61538-196-1}} ==Music video== The promotional video, which was originally made for the Dutch music programme ''[[TopPop]]'' and broadcast on 13 March 1983, was shot in a Dutch military training camp, the band performing the song on a stage in front of a backdrop of fires and explosions provided by the [[Royal Netherlands Army|Dutch Army]]. Towards the end of the video, the band are seen taking cover and abandoning the stage, which was unplanned and genuine since they believed the explosive blasts were getting out of control.{{cite book|first= Rolf |last= Brendel |year= 2014 |title= Nena – Geschichte einer Band |publisher= Aufbau Verlag GmbH & Co |location= Berlin |pages= 131–5 |isbn= 978-3-35105-015-3}} In 2006, the video was used for a $200,000 fundraising campaign for Hurricane Katrina relief efforts. [[MTV Classic (U.S. TV network)|VH1 Classic]] played the English and German versions for an hour straight as part of [[Mercy Corps]]' campaign.{{cite book|first= Laura |last= Barcella |year= 2012 |title= The End: 50 Apocalyptic Visions from Pop Culture That You Should Know About...Before It's Too Late |publisher= Houghton Mifflin Harcourt |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=3N43BP2jqlEC&pg=PA16 |accessdate= 19 June 2017}} ==Chart positions== ===German version=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ====Weekly charts==== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" !Chart (1983–1984) !Peak

{{Infobox person | name = Alex Tomaini | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Scott Alexzander Tomaini | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1989}} | birth_place = | residence = | nationality = {{flag|US|name=American}} | other_names = Alex Zander Morrow
Junior Torture King | known_for = youngest US swordswallower | occupation = sideshow performer | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = [[Al Tomaini]] (grandfather)
[[Judy Tomaini Rock]] (grandmother) {{Cite news | last=Kushner | first=David | author-link=David Kushner | title=I Was a Teenage Freak: In Gibsonton, Florida, the Carny Capital of the Nation, a New Generation of Glass Walkers and Knife Throwers Keeps the Sideshow Alive for at Least One More Summer | newspaper=[[Rolling Stone Magazine]] | volume= | issue=930 | pages=104–106, 108, 110, 112 | date=September 4, 2003 | url=http://gateway.proquest.com/openurl?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2003&res_dat=xri:pqil:res_ver=0.1&rft_val_fmt=ori:format:pl:ebnf:fulltext&res_id=xri:iimp&rft_id=xri:iipaft:aarticle:fulltext:00228592}} (Accessed on November 1, 2008) online version requires registration | website = | footnotes = }} '''Alex Tomaini''' (stage name: '''Alex Zander Morrow'''){{cite interview|last= |first= |subject=Alex Zander Morrow |subjectlink= |interviewer=John Robinson |title=Alex Zander - The Junior Torture King |type= |url=http://www.sideshowworld.com/interviewalexander.html |date=August 1, 2004 |accessdate=2008-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006092153/http://www.sideshowworld.com/interviewalexander.html |archivedate=October 6, 2008 }} is a [[sideshow]] performer. At the age of 14, he officially became the youngest confirmed [[sword swallowing|sword swallower]] in the [[United States]].[http://www.swordswallow.com/records.php Records from Swordswallow.com] (accessed December 22, 2006). He swallowed his first [[sword]] at the 2003 Sword Swallowers Convention in [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]] before an audience of his peers and international [[News media|media]], only four hours after swallowing his first [[Clothes hanger|coat hanger]] as practice.{{cite video | people = Roz Mason (director), Andrew Waterworth (executive producer) | title = Stomachs of Steel | medium = documentary | publisher = [[NHNZ]] / Discovery Channel | date = July 2004}} He later joined a record attempt called "The Big Swallow" in which a group of sword swallowers try to simultaneously swallow as many swords as possible.[http://www.swordswallow.com/news.php News article] on 2003 Big Swallow (accessed December 22, 2006). Alex lost the record to [[Erik Kloeker]] of the Pickled Brothers Sideshow, who is one year younger than Alex. ==See also== *[[Jeannie Tomaini]] (great grandmother) ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070217181003/http://www.offthefence.com/content/programme.php?ID=267 "Stomachs of Steel"] at Offthefence.com *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080821185047/http://bmeworld.com/amago/archives/roadshow/sideshow03.html The Lizard Man - 2nd Annual Sidehsow Gathering 2003] {{DEFAULTSORT:Morrow, Alex Zander}} [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:Sideshow performers]] [[Category:Living people]] {{entertainer-stub}}

An '''aptronym''', '''aptonym''' or '''euonym''' is a [[personal name]] aptly or peculiarly suited to its owner.
==History== The ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' attributes the term to [[Franklin P. Adams]], a writer who coined it as an anagram of ''patronym'', to emphasize "apt".<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |year=2008 |title =aptronym |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/30911/aptronym|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica |edition=Encyclopædia Britannica Online|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc. |accessdate=2008-07-19 |location= |id= }}</ref>
According to Frank Nuessel, in ''The Study of Names'' (1992), an ''aptonym'' is the term used for "people whose names and occupations or situations (e.g., workplace) have a close correspondence."
In the book ''What's in a Name?'' (1996), author [[Paul Dickson (writer)|Paul Dickson]] cites a long list of aptronyms originally compiled by Professor Lewis P. Lipsitt, of [[Brown University]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dickson|first1=Paul|title=What's in a Name? Reflections of an Irrepressible Name Collector|date=1996|publisher=Merriam-Webster|location=Springfield, Mass.|isbn=0-87779-613-0}}</ref> Psychologist [[Carl Jung]] wrote in his book ''[[Synchronicity (book)|Synchronicity]]'' that there was a "sometimes quite grotesque coincidence between a man's name and his peculiarities".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9664000/9664697.stm "When the name fits the job"] BBC. Retrieved 26 July 2013.</ref>
[[Nominative determinism]] is a hypothesis which suggests a causal relationship based on the idea that people tend to be attracted to areas of work that fit their name.
==Notable examples== <!-- DO NOT ADD EXAMPLES WITHOUT A RELIABLE SOURCE STATING THAT IT IS AN APTRONYM, PER CONSENSUS. --> <!-- Alphabetical order, please, and no fictional examples because those are done deliberately. Non-English language aptronyms have their own section elsewhere--> * [[Jules Angst]], German professor of [[psychiatry]], who has published works about [[anxiety]]<ref name="guardian">{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/mind-your-language/2014/oct/31/mind-your-language-nominative-determinism |title= Reckless by name, reckless by nature? (But at least he’s not called Rich White) |last= Nunn |first= Gary }}</ref> * [[Michael Ball (footballer)|Michael Ball]], football player<ref name=macmillan/> * [[Lonzo Ball]], basketball player * [[Colin Bass]], British [[bass guitar|bassist]] in the rock band [[Camel (band)|Camel]]<ref name=guardian/> * [[Lance Bass]], [[Bass (voice type)|bass]] singer for the American pop [[boy band]] [[NSYNC]]<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Holley|first1=Shawn|title=20 20 Smart Lists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hus7DwAAQBAJ&pg=PP28&lpg=PP28&dq=lance+bass+aptronym&source=bl&ots=iHcR7O-dJE&sig=VXlq7Wm8U8Et60WcUiL9KClMGQ0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwi_ivjThZXcAhWBmOAKHWULD_oQ6AEwDnoECAIQAQ#v=onepage&q=lance%20bass%20aptronym&f=false}}</ref> * [[Sara Blizzard]], [[meteorology|meteorologist]] (television weather presenter) for the [[BBC]]<ref name="guardian"/> * [[Usain Bolt]], Jamaican sprinter<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/what-is-aptronym-names-1689129|title=Aptronym - Definitions and Examples in English|last=Nordquist|first=Richard}}</ref> * [[Rosalind Brewer]], executive at [[Starbucks]] and a former director at [[Molson Coors Brewing Company]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Berman|first=Laura|date=September 6, 2017|title=Starbucks Adds Fittingly Named Rosalind Brewer, Sam's Club Veteran, as COO|url=https://www.thestreet.com/story/14295568/1/starbucks-adds-fittingly-named-rosalind-brewer-sam-s-club-veteran-as-coo.html|work=The Street|accessdate=2017-09-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Noah|first=Timothy|date=May 17, 2006|title=Wayne Schmuck, Used-Car Distributor|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/chatterbox/2006/05/wayne_schmuck_usedcar_distributor.html|work=Slate|accessdate=2017-09-14}}</ref> * [[Christopher Coke]], drug lord and cocaine trafficker <ref>{{cite news |last= Haberman |first= Clyde |date= 2011-09-01 |title= "When a Person’s Name Means What It Says" |url= https://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/01/when-a-persons-name-means-what-it-says/ |work= New York Times |access-date= 2 December 2018 }}</ref> * [[Margaret Court]], Australian [[tennis]] player<ref name=macmillan/> * [[Thomas Crapper]], sanitary engineer<ref name=macmillan>{{cite web|work=MacMillan Dictionary|title=BuzzWord: Aptronym|date=4 March 2008|last=Maxwell|first=Kerry|url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/buzzword/entries/aptronym.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|author=Wilton, David|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=QQovEeLHVl0C&pg=PA138|title=Word Myths: Debunking Linguistic Urban Legends|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|page=138}}</ref> * [[Josh Earnest]], the third [[White House Press Secretary|press secretary]] for the [[Obama Administration]] ([[Stephen Colbert]] observed, "What a name for a press secretary. Josh Earnest. His name literally means, 'Just kidding, but seriously.'"<ref name=Politico>{{cite news|last1=Topaz|first1=Jonathan|title=Stephen Colbert to ‘quitter’ Jay Carney: Man up!|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/06/jay-carney-stephen-colbert-quitter-comedy-central-108107.html|accessdate=17 January 2015|work=[[Politico]]|date=24 June 2014}}</ref>) * [[Cecil Fielder]] and [[Prince Fielder]], baseball players<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ranker.com/list/famous-people-with-literal-names/jordan-love|title=Famous People with Literal Names|last=Love|first=Jordan}}</ref> * [[Franz Fischler]], former European Union Commissioner for Fisheries * [[Amy Freeze]], American meteorologist<ref name=slate/> * [[George Francis Train]], American Railroad Entrepreneur * [[Theodore Gill]], American ichthyologist * [[Igor Judge, Baron Judge|Igor Judge]], English judge and [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales|Lord Chief Justice]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/10218954/Farewell-to-a-doughty-champion-of-liberty-and-the-public-interest.html|title=Farewell to a doughty champion of liberty and the public interest|last=Johnston|first=Philip|date=2013-08-02|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> * [[John Laws (judge)|John Laws]], English judge and [[Lord Justice of Appeal]] * [[Chris Moneymaker]], American poker player and [[2003 World Series of Poker]] champion<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/25/us/a-player-called-money-wins-world-poker-title.html|title=A Player Called 'Money' Wins World Poker Title|last=Wilgoren|first=Jodi|date=2003-05-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> * [[Francine Prose]], American novelist<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sánchez Canales|first1=Gustavo|editor1-last=Aarons|editor1-first=Victoria|editor2-last=Sánchez Canales|editor2-first=Gustavo|title=Bernard Malamud: A Centennial Tribute|date=2016|publisher=Wayne State University Press|location=Detroit, Michigan|isbn=9780814341148|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3qohDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT89&lpg=PT89&dq=francine+prose+aptronym&source=bl&ots=QGR-lxCLac&sig=SJWXu0f4Tom0ZHUCONCvzJjzf5Q&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQyb2fiPLTAhXhwVQKHWcQAqAQ6AEIKDAB#v=onepage&q=francine%20prose%20aptronym&f=false|accessdate=27 June 2017|chapter="What's in a Name?": Aptronyms and Archetypes in Bernard Malamud's ''The Assistant'' and ''The Fixer''}}</ref> * [[Marilyn vos Savant]], American columnist who has been cited for having the world's highest recorded [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]]<ref>{{cite book |last= Elster |first= Charles Harrington |title= What in the Word? |location= Orlando, FL |publisher= Harcourt |year= 2005 |page= 109 |isbn=}}</ref> * [[Anthony Weiner]], American politician involved in [[sexting]] scandals<ref name=slate>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/lexicon_valley/2016/03/14/how_trump_s_name_is_an_aptronym.html|title=Do Our Names Shape Our Destinies? Trump’s Might.|last=Johnson|first=Theodore R.|work=Slate|date=14 March 2016}}</ref> * [[William Wordsworth]], English poet and advocate for the extension of [[British copyright law]]<ref>{{Cite book|author=Wordsworth, William|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-ZcUAAAAQAAJ|title=The Prose Works of William Wordsworth|editor= Alexander B. Grosart|location=London|publisher=Edward Moxon, Son and Co.|year=1876|page=21}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Swartz, Richard G.|jstor=438162|title=Wordsworth, Copyright, and the Commodities of Genius|journal= [[Modern Philology]] |volume=89|issue=4|year=1992|pages=482–509}}</ref><ref name=macmillan/>
<!-- DO NOT ADD EXAMPLES WITHOUT A RELIABLE SOURCE THAT USES THE TERM "APTRONYM". SEE TALK PAGE FOR MORE INFORMATION. -->
===Inaptronyms=== Some aptronyms are [[irony|ironic]] rather than descriptive, being called '''inaptronyms''' by [[Gene Weingarten]] of the ''[[Washington Post]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2006/07/11/DI2006071100616.html|title=Chatological Humor* (UPDATED 7.21.06)|author=Gene Weingarten|date=July 18, 2006|work=Washington Post}}</ref> A notable example is the former [[Archbishop]] of [[Manila]], [[Jaime Sin]] who in 1976 was made a [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinal]] by [[Pope Paul VI]], thus becoming known as "[[seven deadly sins|Cardinal Sin]]".<ref name="guardian"/> <!-- DO NOT ADD EXAMPLES WITHOUT A RELIABLE SOURCE STATING THAT IT IS AN INAPTRONYM, PER CONSENSUS. --> * [[Frank Beard (musician)|Frank Beard]], an American musician who, until recently, was the only member of rock band [[ZZ Top]] without a beard<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kmhk.com/zz-top-drummer-frank-beard-finally-grows-one/|title=ZZ Top Drummer Frank Beard Finally Grows One|website=103.7 The Hawk|access-date=2018-01-06}}</ref> * [[Don Black (white supremacist)|Don Black]], [[White supremacy|white supremacist]]<ref name="guardian" /> * [[Peter Bowler (cricketer)|Peter Bowler]], [[cricket]]er (in fact, primarily a [[batsman]])<ref name="guardian"/> * [[Samuel Foote]], a comic actor who lost a leg in a horseriding accident in 1766, and made jokes on stage about "Foote and leg, and leg and foot"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clarke|first1=Norma|title=Samuel Foote, the one-legged wonder|url=http://www.the-tls.co.uk/tls/public/article1179826.ece|accessdate=14 December 2015|publisher=The Times Literary Supplement|date=28 December 2014}}</ref> * [[Danielle Outlaw|Danielle Outlaw]], [[Chief of Police|Chief of Police]] at [[Portland Police Bureau|Portland Police Bureau]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kptv.com/story/36512715/qa-with-new-portland-police-chief-danielle-outlaw|title=Q&A with new Portland Police Chief Danielle Outlaw|website=Fox 12 Oregon|access-date=2018-08-13}}</ref> * [[Larry Playfair]], [[NHL]] defenseman known for his [[fighting in ice hockey|fighting]]<ref>{{cite web|title=6 Biggest Goons In Buffalo Sabres’ History|url=http://www.rantsports.com/nhl/2014/01/19/6-biggest-goons-in-buffalo-sabres-history/#slide_6|website=Rant Sports|accessdate=14 December 2015|date=19 January 2014}}</ref> <!-- DO NOT ADD EXAMPLES WITHOUT A RELIABLE SOURCE STATING THAT IT IS AN INAPTRONYM, PER CONSENSUS. -->

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{About|the Broadway musical revue|the fan frenzy towards The Beatles|Beatlemania}} {{Infobox Musical |name= Beatlemania |image= Beatlemania Playbill cover.jpg |image_size=0 |caption= Broadway ''Playbill'' cover |music= [[The Beatles]] |lyrics= The Beatles |book= [[Bob Gill (artist)|Bob Gill]], [[Robert Rabinowitz (artist)|Robert Rabinowitz]], [[Lynda Obst]] |basis= The life and music of The Beatles |productions= 1977 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] |awards= |tagline = Not the Beatles, but an incredible simulation }} '''''Beatlemania''''' was a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] [[musical theater|musical]] [[revue]] focused on the music of [[The Beatles]] as it related to the events and changing attitudes of the tumultuous 1960s. A "[[rockumentary]]," advertised as "''Not the Beatles, but an incredible simulation'',"<ref name=4Young>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1977/04/05/75061713.html?pageNumber=41 "Four Young Musicians to Simulate Beatles,"] ''New York Times'' (April 5, 1977).</ref> it ran from 1977 to 1979<ref>Itzkoff, Dave. [https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/08/beatles-concert-show-let-it-be-coming-to-broadway/ "ARTSBEAT; Beatles Concert Show Coming to Broadway,"] ''New York Times'' (May 9, 2013).</ref> for a total of 1,006 performances.
== Synopsis == ''Beatlemania'' took the form of a roughly chronological history of The Beatles via their music. About 50<ref name=4Young /> songs were performed during the show. Other than some onstage banter, there was very little dialogue during the production, which consisted mostly of exact re-enactments of the Beatles' music. The multimedia production was notable for its extensive use of backdrops, slides, newspaper headlines, and video footage to evoke the 1960s and iconic Beatle moments.<ref name=Rockwell /><ref name=Klein />
== Productions == Beatles [[tribute bands]] predated ''Beatlemania'' — notably [[Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles|Rain]] (which debuted in 1975)<ref name=rgj>Sion, Mike. [http://www.rgj.com/story/life/2015/01/21/rain-new-generation-takes-reins-beatles-tribute/22132047/ "Rain: New generation takes reins of Beatles tribute,"] ''Reno Gazette-Journal'' (January 23, 2015).</ref> — but ''Beatlemania'' was the first production to create a full multimedia theatrical experience.
Originally conceived and produced by Steve Leber and David Krebs,<ref name=4Young /> ''Beatlemania'' debuted in Boston at the [[Colonial Theatre (Boston)|Colonial Theatre]] in April 1977. It premiered on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Winter Garden Theatre]] on May 31, 1977 (after previewing since May 26 — although no critics were invited),<ref name=Klein>Klein, Alvin. [http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1980/11/16/112061666.html?pageNumber=340 'Beatlemania' Captures the Panorama of a Decade,"] ''New York Times'' (November 16, 1980).</ref> with cast members Joe Pecorino ("[[John Lennon|John]]"), Mitch Weissman ("[[Paul McCartney|Paul]]"), [[Les Fradkin]] ("[[George Harrison|George]]"), and Justin McNeill ("[[Ringo Starr|Ringo]]").<ref name=Rockwell>Rockwell, John. [http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1977/06/17/92246641.html?pageNumber=53 "Stage: 'Beatlemania's' Formula Is Sincerely Flattering,"] ''New York Times'' (June 17, 1977).</ref>
Quickly achieving sellout status without ever having an official "opening night", ''Beatlemania'' saw great success and coverage in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', ''[[Us (magazine)|Us]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. For the first six months, every ticket for the show was sold out.{{cn|date=March 2016}}
The production was nominated for the 1978 [[Tony Award]] for Best Lighting Design by designer [[Jules Fisher]], while the sound engineer was longtime industry veteran William (Bill) Rofot. Season 3 of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'''s ''[[Weekend Update]]'' (airing March 15, 1978) parodied the show when [[Dan Aykroyd]] mentioned "''Beatlemaniamania'': not ''Beatlemania'', but an incredible simulation."<ref>[http://snltranscripts.jt.org/77/77oupdate.phtml "77o: Christopher Lee / Meat Loaf: Weekend Update with Jane Curtin & Dan Aykroyd,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180219090708/http://snltranscripts.jt.org/77/77oupdate.phtml |date=February 19, 2018 }} Saturday Night Live Transcripts website. Accessed March 19, 2016.</ref>
''Beatlemania'' ran until October 17, 1979, for a total of 1006 performances; grossing more than $40 million.<ref>[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20080198,00.html "Picks and Pans Review: Beatlemania—the Movie,"] ''People'' Vol. 16, No. 11 (September 14, 1981).</ref> During its New York run, the show moved to the [[Lunt-Fontanne Theatre]] and finally the [[Palace Theatre, New York|Palace Theatre]].
As the show expanded in its formative years, over 50 original cast members formed 10 "bunks" (or casts of a single set of four). As the New York show continued its run, shows were opened in Los Angeles, Chicago, Cincinnati, and London. At its peak, ''Beatlemania'' had several permanent shows in several cities around the world and several semi-temporary shows in many more cities in the U.S. and the rest of the world.
After closing on Broadway, the ''Beatlemania Bus and Truck Tour'' began, running until 1983 and touring across the United States and worldwide. Short-term tours of Australia, Europe, Asia, and Africa were produced after 1982.
An updated show, ''With the Beatles'', was created as a tribute to the musical in 1983.
The 1986 decision in a lawsuit by the Beatles production company [[Apple Corps]] officially ended the show for a period of time, but revival tours still continue today, under such names as ''Beatlemania: Yesterday and Today''<ref>Weizel, Richard. [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/13/nyregion/years-of-yesterdays-and-yeah-yeah-yeah.html "Years of Yesterdays And Yeah, Yeah, Yeah,"] ''New York Times'' (May 13, 2001).</ref> and ''Beatlemania Now''.<ref>Plasko, Joe. [http://www.tnonline.com/2010/sep/13/beatlemania-now "Beatlemania Now: Tribute paid to the Fab Four and the 1960's,"] ''[[Times News (Pennsylvania)|Times News]]'' (September 13, 2010).</ref>
== ''Beatlemania: The Album'' == In 1978, ''Beatlemania'' released a self-titled original cast album of the show which included contributions from the first and second cast of performers from the show (as well as five additional off-stage musicians — keyboards; violin; cello; sax/flute/recorder; trumpet/picollo trumpet and oboe). Released on [[Arista Records]] in 1978, the album received warm audience reaction, even placing on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] for several weeks, before falling into obscurity.
Tracks from the album included most but not all of the original show's song list, and several of the tracks were either re-recorded entirely or partially re-recorded in the studio. Cast members that appear on the album include Mitch Weissman, Joe Pecorino, [[Les Fradkin]], Justin McNeill, Randy Clark, Reed Kailing, P. M. Howard, and Bobby Taylor.
== ''Beatlemania: The Movie'' == After three years of production USA Video Productions took an interest in making a film version of the ''Beatlemania'' stage show. After a brief contract negotiation, ''Beatlemania: The Movie'' began production in late 1980 (shortly before the [[murder of John Lennon]]). Directed by Joseph Manduke, the film's cast featured Mitch Weissman (bass guitar; "Paul"), David Leon (rhythm guitar; "John"), Tom Teeley (lead guitar; "George"), and Ralph Castelli (drums; "Ringo").<ref name=Rosenbaum>Rosenbaum, Jonathan. [http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/beatlemania/Film?oid=1056339 "Beatlemania,"] ''Chicago Reader''. Accessed March 21, 2016.</ref>
''Beatlemania: The Movie'' was released in the summer of 1981 and received negative reviews. [[Janet Maslin]] of ''The New York Times'', "''Beatlemania'' was a horror on the stage, and it's even more of a horror at close range, where the seams really show. This isn't a loving impersonation, or even an honest one. It's cheap, disingenuous and loathsome."<ref>Maslin, Janet. [https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/movies/beatlemania-their-lives-our-times.html 'BEATLEMANIA,' THEIR LIVES, OUR TIMES,"] ''New York Times'' (August 7, 1981).</ref> [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] of the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' wrote, "My idea of hell is being forced at gunpoint to resee this ... atrocity, ... based on a terrible stage musical."<ref name=Rosenbaum /> Other observers{{who|date=March 2016}} criticized the film for being too artsy and not worthy of being associated with the stageshow; plans for a follow-up film were immediately cancelled.{{cn|date=March 2016}}
== Apple Corps lawsuit== In 1979, [[Apple Corps]] sued show creator Steve Leber and ''Beatlemania''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s producers, alleging that Apple Corps owned various publicity rights and trademarks, and Leber and others "appropriated to themselves" the value of those trademarks and the Beatles' goodwill and fame without paying for it. In 1986, Los Angeles Superior Court judge Paul Breckenridge found in favor of Apple Corps, and ordered Leber and Beatlemania Inc. to pay Apple $5.6 million, plus 7% interest from September 1979. He also found that Apple was entitled to a court order barring the further unconsented use or exploitation of the Beatles, and that Beatlemania's actions "amounted to virtually a complete appropriation of the Beatles' persona" without their consent.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://articles.latimes.com/1986-06-05/entertainment/ca-9832_1_apple-corps | title = Beatlemania Co. Loses Apple Suit | work = LA Times | date = June 5, 1986 | accessdate = July 6, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=Reuters /> The judge also found that [[Ely Landau]] and the This Is The Week That Was Beatlemania Company, which produced the ''Beatlemania'' film, were liable $2 million and 7% interest, also payable to Apple Corps.<ref name=Reuters>Reuters. [https://www.nytimes.com/1986/06/05/movies/beatlemania-ordered-to-pay-10-million.html "'Beatlemania' Ordered To Pay $10 Million,"] ''New York Times'' (June 5, 1986).</ref>
==Music==
The musical numbers in the show, based on the Broadway opening, were:<ref name=playbill>{{cite web|title=Playbill: Beatlemania August 1977|publisher=[[Playbill]]|url=http://www.playbill.com/playbillpagegallery/inside-playbill?asset=00000150-aea7-d936-a7fd-eef7517d0000&type=InsidePlaybill&slide=3|accessdate=2018-03-01}}</ref>
{{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act 1 *"[[Let's Twist Again]]" <small>([[Kal Mann]] & [[Dave Appell]])</small> *"[[Roll Over Beethoven]]" <small>([[Chuck Berry]])</small> *"[[Bye Bye Love (The Everly Brothers song)|Bye Bye Love]]" <small>([[Felice Bryant|Felice]] & [[Boudleaux Bryant]])</small> *"[[Hound Dog (song)|Hound Dog]]" <small>([[Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller]])</small> *"[[I Wanna Hold Your Hand]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[She Loves You]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Help! (song)|Help!]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[If I Fell]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Can't Buy Me Love]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Day Tripper]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Yesterday (Beatles song)|Yesterday]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[We Can Work It Out]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Nowhere Man (song)|Nowhere Man]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[A Day in the Life]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Strawberry Fields Forever]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Magical Mystery Tour (song)|Magical Mystery Tour]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> {{col-break}}
;Act 2 *"[[Lady Madonna]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[The Fool on the Hill]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Got to Get You into My Life]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Michelle (song)|Michelle]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Get Back]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Come Together]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[With a Little Help from My Friends]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[All You Need Is Love]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Revolution (Beatles song)|Revolution]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Helter Skelter (song)|Helter Skelter]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Hey Jude]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[I Am the Walrus]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Here Comes the Sun]]"<small>([[George Harrison]])</small> *"[[The Long and Winding Road]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> *"[[Let It Be (song)|Let It Be]]" <small>([[Lennon–McCartney]])</small> {{col-end}}
== Cast members == {{Refimprove section|date=February 2016}} Because of the vocal strain (especially for "Paul") involved in doing 10 or more shows per week, each production utilized two (2) casts or "bunks," as they were dubbed by musical director Sandy Yaguda. The Original Broadway production featured Bunk 1 (Mitch Weissman, Joe Pecorino, Les Fradkin and Justin McNeill).<ref name=Rockwell /> and Bunk 2 (Randy Clark, Reed Kailing, P.M. Howard, and Bobby Taylor). Subsequent cast members of the Leber-Krebs production are known as "Original" cast members, as the show expanded with several touring casts.
Casts and casting became independent after 1984 as revival and current casts tour under many different Beatle-related nomenclatures. (It is common practice for other Beatles tribute bands to promote themselves falsely as "Original Broadway Cast".){{cn|date=March 2016}}
=== John Lennon === *[[Joe Pecorino]] *Randy Clark *Michael Palaikis (''deceased'') *David Leon — also played with ''[[Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles]]'' *Caspar McCloud (later swapped roles with Marshall Crenshaw) *[[Marshall Crenshaw]] — performed in Hollywood and San Francisco productions as well as the touring production<ref name="koda">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/crenshaw_marshall/artist.jhtml#biographyEnd|title=Marshall Crenshaw/MTV|accessdate=June 17, 2010|last=Koda|first=Cub|work=All Music Guide}}</ref> *Mark Vaccacio (''deceased'') *Peter McGann *Bob Williford *Robert Wirth *Jim Riddle<ref name=Klein /> (''deceased'') *Steve Landes — currently a member of ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *Joe Palermo
=== Paul McCartney === *Mitch Weissman<ref name=playbill/> *Reed Kailing *[[The Cast of Beatlemania|Lenie Colacino]] *Alan LeBoeuf — also played with ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *[[Glen Burtnik|Glen Burtnick]] *[[Tony Kishman]] *Joey Curatolo — currently a member of ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *Jim Odom *Jimmy Rooney * Bobby Grant *Don Linares *Jim Cushing *John Redgate *Billy J. Ray
=== George Harrison === *[[Les Fradkin]]<ref name=playbill/> *P. M. Howard *Tom Teeley — also played with ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *Rob Laufer *Bobby Diebold *Richie Gomez *Jimmy Pou — currently a member of ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *Jimmy Rooney *Bob Miller *Peter Santora *Chris Gavin *Joe Bithorn<ref name=Klein /> — currently a member of ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *Richi Ray
=== Ringo Starr === *Justin McNeill<ref name=playbill/> *Bobby Taylor *Bennett Gale<ref name=Klein /> *Louie Colucci *Ralph Castelli — currently a member of ''Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles'' *Sy Goraieb *Bobby Forte *[[Al Sapienza]] *Rick Bloom *Phil LoMedico *Gemma Press *Cho Paquet
==Awards and nominations== ===Original Broadway production=== {| class="wikitable" width="95%" |- ! width="5%"| Year ! width="20%"| Award Ceremony ! width="45%"| Category ! width="20%"| Nominee ! width="10%"| Result |- | rowspan="13"| 1977 | rowspan="11"| [[Tony Award]] | [[Tony Award for Best Lighting Design|Best Lighting Design (Play or Musical)]] | [[Jules Fisher]] | {{nom}} |- |}

{{Infobox video game |title = Bo Jackson Baseball |image = Bo Jackson Baseball Coverart.png |caption = Packaging for the NES version. |developer = [[Krome Studios Melbourne|Beam Software]] |publisher = [[Data East]]
[[Mindscape]] |designer = [[Scott Orr]]
[[Denny Thorley]] |composer = Marshall Parker |released = '''NES:''' {{vgrelease|NA|October 1990{{cite web| url = http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/nes/data/587149.html| title = Release information (NES version) | publisher = [[GameFAQs]]| date = | accessdate = 2008-07-25}}}} '''MS-DOS:''' {{vgrelease|NA|1991{{cite web| url = http://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/928616-bo-jackson-baseball| title = Release information (MS-DOS version) | publisher = GameFAQs| date = | accessdate = 2012-01-17}}}} '''Amiga:''' {{vgrelease|NA|1992{{cite web| url = http://www.gamefaqs.com/amiga/643910-bo-jackson-baseball| title = Release information (Amiga version) | publisher = GameFAQs| date = | accessdate = 2012-01-17}}|EU|1992}} |genre = [[Sports game|Sports]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]]
[[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Nintendo Entertainment System|NES]], [[MS-DOS]], [[Amiga]] }} '''''Bo Jackson Baseball''''' is a [[baseball]] video game that was released for the [[Nintendo Entertainment System]], [[Amiga|Commodore Amiga]] and [[IBM PC]]-compatibles. The game features athlete [[Bo Jackson]], who at the time of the game's release was a star in professional baseball and a former professional [[American football|football]] player. In Europe, the game was released by [[Mindscape]] as '''''TV Sports: Baseball''''', part of the ''TV Sports'' series that included ''[[TV Sports: Basketball]]'' and other games based on hockey and American football. ==Gameplay== [[File:BoJacksonBaseballScreenshot.png|175px|left|thumb|Someone has successfully hit the ball and it looks like it's going to go towards the back wall of the stadium.]] An option allows the player to play anywhere from five to nine innings. Players can choose to throw five different kinds of pitches either slowly, at a normal speed, or very rapidly.{{cite web | url = http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=90| title = Pitching information | publisher = [[allgame]]| date = | accessdate = 2008-08-09}} [[Nintendo Power]] gave this game a 2.8 out of 5 in their September 1991 review while [[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] issued a 4.25 out of 10 review in their October 1991 issue of their magazine. Players can either play in exhibition mode or playoff mode. Either one or two players can participate. In addition to those options, a ''CPU vs CPU'' mode and a ''CPU vs CPU quick mode'' are available in order to quicken up a tournament; the purpose is to see the stats of that particular match and quickly end tournaments. The game uses city names but not the team names because of not having any proper licensing with Major League Baseball.{{cite web | url = http://www.mobygames.com/game/bo-jackson-baseball| title = Additional release information | publisher = [[MobyGames]]| date = | accessdate = 2011-03-14}} However, the players are purely fictional and they cannot be edited. Some of the player names are parodies of real life baseball players (such as Baltimore's "Kenrip" being a not-so-subtle parody of [[Cal Ripken]]). There is even a [[cheat code]] that allows players to play as an all-Bo Jackson baseball team.{{cite web | url = http://www.cheatscodesguides.com/nes-cheats/bo-jackson-baseball/| title = All-Bo Team Information | publisher = Cheat Codes Guides| date = | accessdate = 2008-07-25}} The Commodore Amiga version includes a [[Sports league|league]] mode that the NES version doesn't have.{{cite web | url = http://www.lemonamiga.com/games/docs.php?id=229| title = Commodore Amiga instruction manual for ''Bo Jackson Baseball'' | publisher = Lemon Amiga| date = | accessdate = 2008-08-09}} Also, the Amiga version of ''Bo Jackson Baseball'' has enhanced 16-bit graphics that are superior to the NES version.{{cite web | url = http://hol.abime.net/3405| title = Commodore Amiga information for ''Bo Jackson Baseball'' | publisher = Abime| date = | accessdate = 2008-08-09}} {{Video game reviews | Allgame = {{Rating|2|5}} | EGM = (4.25/10) | NP = (2.8/5) }} ==Reception== ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'' stated that the IBM version of ''Bo Jackson'' was best as an arcade game and, because of its lack of real players' statistics, less successful than competitors as a simulation.{{cite news | url=http://www.cgwmuseum.org/galleries/index.php?year=1992&pub=2&id=94 | title=Bo Knows Arcade Baseball | work=Computer Gaming World | date=May 1992 | accessdate=24 November 2013 | author=Rogers, Win | pages=59}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bo Jackson Baseball}} [[Category:1991 video games]] [[Category:Amiga games]] [[Category:Baseball video games]] [[Category:Bo Jackson]] men|Jackson]] [[Category:Video games based on real people]] [[Category:Black people in art]]

The '''British Blues Awards''' were inaugurated in 2010. The prize was awarded in various categories, such as 'Male vocals', 'Female vocals', 'Guitarist', 'Bass player' and 'Keyboard player', 'Blues band', 'Young artist', 'Blues album', 'Blues festival' and 'Lifetime achievement'.
The Awards were suspended in 2017, due to technical problems surrounding the validity of the online public voting system, which over time had become susceptible to abuse.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.britishbluesawards.com/home/4581355856|title=Home - British Blues Awards|website=Britishbluesawards.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref>
== British Blues Awards Hall of Fame == The entrants to the "British Blues Awards Hall of Fame", who have won a category three years in a row, are shown below. Members of the Hall of Fame can no longer be nominated for the British Blues Awards in the respective category.<ref name="Hof"/> * [[Matt Schofield]] – Guitarist 2010–2012 * Andy Graham – Bass player 2010–2012 * [[Paul Jones (singer)|Paul Jones]] – Harmonica player 2010–2012 * [[Joe Bonamassa]] – Overseas artist 2010–2012 * [[Ian Siegal]] – Male vocals 2011–2013 * The Paul Jones Rhythm and Blues Show – Blues broadcaster 2011 (exception to the three-year rule) * Hebden Bridge – Blues festival 2012–2014 * [[King King (band)|King King]] – Band 2012–2014
==Awards== The following is a list in chronological order of the award winners in the various categories.<ref name="Past"/>
=== Male vocals === * 2010: [[Oli Brown]] * 2011: [[Ian Siegal]] * 2012: Ian Siegal * 2013: Ian Siegal * 2014: [[The Nimmo Brothers|Alan Nimmo]] * 2015: Alan Nimmo * 2016: Alan Nimmo
=== Female vocals === * 2010: [[Joanne Shaw Taylor]] * 2011: Joanne Shaw Taylor * 2012: [[Chantel McGregor]] * 2013: Chantel McGregor * 2014: [[Jo Harman]] * 2015: [[Dani Wilde]] * 2016: Rebecca Downes
=== Blues band === * 2010: [[Ian Siegal]] Band * 2011: [[Oli Brown]] Band * 2012: [[King King (band)|King King]] * 2013: King King * 2014: King King * 2015: [[The Nimmo Brothers]] * 2016: The Nimmo Brothers
=== Harmonica player === * 2010: [[Paul Jones (singer)|Paul Jones]] * 2011: Paul Jones * 2012: Paul Jones * 2013: [[Paul Lamb (musician)|Paul Lamb]] * 2014: Paul Lamb * 2015: Paul Lamb * 2016: [[Mark Feltham (musician)|Mark Feltham]]
=== Guitarist === * 2010: [[Matt Schofield]] * 2011: Matt Schofield * 2012: Matt Schofield * 2013: [[Chantel McGregor]] * 2014: Chantel McGregor * 2015: [[Aynsley Lister]] * 2016: [[Laurence Jones (musician)|Laurence Jones]]
=== Acoustic act === * 2012: [[Ian Siegal]] * 2013: [[Marcus Bonfanti]] * 2014: Marcus Bonfanti * 2015: Ian Siegal * 2016: Ian Siegal
=== Bass player === * 2010: Andy Graham * 2011: Andy Graham * 2012: Andy Graham * 2013: Lindsay Coulson * 2014: Lindsay Coulson * 2015: [[Norman Watt-Roy]] * 2016: Lindsay Coulson
=== Keyboard player === * 2010: Jonny Henderson * 2011: Jonny Henderson * 2012: [[Paddy Milner]] * 2013: Bennett Holland * 2014: Steve Watts * 2015: Paddy Milner * 2016: Paul Long
=== Drummer === * 2010: Simon Dring * 2011: Wayne Proctor * 2012: Stephen Cutmore * 2014: Wayne Proctor * 2015: Wayne Proctor * 2015: Wayne Proctor * 2016: Andrew Naumann
=== Instrumentalist === * 2010: Son Henry * 2011: Son Henry * 2012: Becky Tate * 2013: Becky Tate * 2014: Sarah Skinner * 2015: Becky Tate * 2016: Becky Tate
=== Young artist === * 2010: [[Oli Brown]] * 2011: [[Chantel McGregor]] * 2012: Oli Brown * 2013: Dan Owen / Lucy Zirins * 2014: [[Laurence Jones (musician)|Laurence Jones]] * 2015: Laurence Jones * 2016: Laurence Jones
=== Blues festival === * 2010: Blues On The Farm * 2011: Great British Rhythm And Blues Festival * 2012: Hebden Bridge Blues Festival * 2013: Hebden Bridge Blues Festival * 2014: Hebden Bridge Blues Festival * 2015: Upton Blues Festival * 2016: Upton Blues Festival
=== Overseas artist === * 2010: [[Joe Bonamassa]] * 2011: Joe Bonamassa * 2012: Joe Bonamassa * 2013: [[Walter Trout]] * 2014: Walter Trout * 2015: Walter Trout * 2016: [[Buddy Guy]]
=== Blues broadcaster === * 2011: [[Paul Jones (singer)|Paul Jones]] (Category replaced as below)
=== Independent blues broadcaster === * 2012: [[Gary Grainger]] * 2013: Dave Raven * 2014: Dave Watkins * 2015: Dave Raven * 2016: Paul Long
=== Lifetime achievement === * 2010: Colin Staples * 2011: [[Paul Jones (singer)|Paul Jones]] * 2012: [[Paul Oliver]] * 2013: [[Mike Vernon (producer)|Mike Vernon]] / Barry Middleton * 2014: Philip Guy Davis / Bill & Joyce Harrison * 2015: Paul Dean New Crawdaddy Club * 2016: Pete Feenstra
=== Blues album === * 2010: ''Heads, Tails & Aces'' – [[Matt Schofield]] * 2011: ''Heads I Win Tails You Lose'' – [[Oli Brown]] * 2012: ''Take My Hand'' – [[King King (band)|King King]] * 2013: ''Candy Store Kid'' – [[Ian Siegal]] and the Mississippi Mudbloods * 2014: ''Standing in the Shadows'' – King King * 2015: ''Going Back Home'' – [[Wilko Johnson]] and [[Roger Daltrey]] * 2016: ''Reaching For The Light'' – King King
=== Kevin Thorpe Award for Songwriter of the Year === * 2011: [[Joanne Shaw Taylor]] for "Same As It Never Was" * 2012: [[Marcus Bonfanti]] for "The Bittersweet" * 2013: [[Ian Siegal]] for "I Am The Train" * 2014: [[Aynsley Lister]] * 2015: Katie Bradley and Dudley Ross * 2016: [[King King (band)|King King]]
=== Song === * 2014: "Home" – [[Aynsley Lister]] * 2015: "Mud Honey" – [[Joanne Shaw Taylor]] * 2016: "Rush Hour" – [[King King (band)|King King]]
=== Barry Middleton Memorial Award for Emerging Artist === * 2014: King Size Slim * 2015: [[Kaz Hawkins]] * 2016: Rebecca Downes
=== British blues great === * 2015: [[John Mayall]] and [[Chris Barber]] * 2016: Papa George and The Hoax<ref name="auto"/><ref name="Hof">{{cite web|url=http://www.britishbluesawards.com/hall-of-fame/4581367378|title=British Blues Awards – Hall of Fame|website=Britishbluesawards.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Past">{{cite web|url=http://www.britishbluesawards.com/past-winners/4581356393|title=British Blues Awards – Past Winners|website=Britishbluesawards.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bluesdoodles.com/bluesdoodles/british-blues-awards-results-2015/|title=2015 British Blues Awards RESULTS - Bluesdoodles|date=15 September 2015|website=Bluesdoodles.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.antonydannecker.com/marcus-bonfanti-ten-years/|title=Marcus Bonfanti and Ten Years After|date=30 January 2015|website=Antonydannecker.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bluecommotion.com/awards/uk-blues-awards-2018-2-nominations-female-vocals-album-of-the-year-2017.html|title=Zoe Schwarz Blue Commotion - UK Blues Awards 2018 - 2 nominations: Female Vocals & Album of the Year (2017)|website=Bluecommotion.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rufrecords.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=292:british-blues-awards&catid=12&Itemid=194&lang=en|title=British Blues Award winners announced|first=Sabine|last=Ruf|website=Rufrecords.de|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.waltertrout.com/single-post/2017/06/18/British-Blues-Awards-2013---Winner|title=Walter Trout - United States|website=WalterTrout.com|accessdate=30 June 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Chilean electronic music''' refers to the [[electronic music]] genre and its subgenres produced in [[Chile]] or by Chileans.
==History== The origins of electronic music in Chile can be found as far back as 1958, when physicist [[Werner Meyer-Eppler]] visited Chile. As a result of his visit, experimentation with electronic music gained support from the scientific community and an electronic music laboratory was established.
In 1959, Jose Visencio Asuar published a thesis entitled "Generación mecánica y electrónica del sonido musical" (Mechanical and Electronic Generation of Musical Sound), and to demonstrate his thesis he composed "Variaciones espectrales" (Spectral Variations), the first piece of electronic music in Chile.
In 1966, at the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Chile | Universidad Católica]], Samuel Claro released his second electronic music album, ''Estudio N°1''.
Asuar released ''Estudio Aletorio'' in 1962 and ''Ambientes Sonoros'' in 1967. Both records were released in Germany (Karlsruhe) and Venezuela (Caracas).
In 1968, Tomás Lefever composed 19 electronic tracks and released ''Klesis'', a compilation album containing works by Amenábar and Asuar.<ref>{{cite book |last=Claro |first=Samuel |authorlink=Samuel |last2=Urrutia Blondel |first2=Jorge |authorlink2=Jorge Urrutia Blondel |date=1973 |title=Historia de la musica en Chile |edition=1st |url=http://www.memoriachilena.cl/archivos2/pdfs/MC0033099.pdf/ |accessdate= August 29, 2014}}</ref>
It is not clear when exactly the electronic music movement as it is known today reached Chile. At the beginning of the 1990s a small underground movement had emerged, with DJs such as [[Cristian Vogel]], [[Ricardo Villalobos]], [[Matías Aguayo]] and [[Sergio Orrego]], the opening of the specialist store Background, and small scale events like “Barracudas” in 1992, “Corriente Alterna” (1993), “Distrito Distinto” (1993), “Background” (1994), “Avanzada multimedia” (1994), “Frontera Final” (1995) and “Spandex Parties” taking place through the 1990s. However, most commentators see the true birth of electronica in Chile at the Alacran Peninsula in the city of [[Arica]], in an event that took place during the solar eclipse of November 1994.<ref>[http://www.zona.cl/download/pdf/rave.pdf “CUANDO LA LUNA CHOCO CON EL SOL” (When the moon crash with the sun)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508223650/http://www.zona.cl/download/pdf/rave.pdf |date=2014-05-08 }} Originally from Zona de contacto, zona.cl by Hernán Roríguez Matte, November 18, 1994</ref>
The solar eclipse took place on November 3, 1994, with excellent views available in northern Chilean cities such as Arica, drawing astronomers from around the world to observe the rare phenomenon in the area’s [[Astronomy in Chile|uniquely clear skies]]. A group of [[electronic music|electronica]] fans and DJs decided to use the eerie eclipse landscape as a backdrop to host Chile's first rave.<ref>[http://euphorianews.wordpress.com/2008/01/27/articulando-la-electronica-en-chile/ ARTICULANDO LA ELECTRÓNICA EN CHILE] taken from ''Euphoria'' magazine, February 03, 2008, Santiago, Chile</ref> The event was sponsored by the German clothing manufacturer Pash and took place outdoors in the Scorpion Peninsula, opposite to the historic [[Morro de Arica]]. Ravers could observe the eclipse and wait for its shadow to pass, with electronic music as a soundtrack. DJs who took part in the rave included [[John Acquaviva]], [[Richie Hawtin]], [[Ricardo Villalobos]], [[Derrick May (musician)|Derrick May]], [[Pascal (musician)|Pascal]], Siddhartha and [[Adrian]].
Though it was a small event, the Alacran rave has gained near legendary status in Chile and has become a landmark in the country's electronic scene.<ref>[http://euphorianews.wordpress.com/2010/05/17/desde-la-revista-la-noche EUPHORIA, 18 AÑOS DESARROLLANDO LA CULTURA DE LA MÚSICA ELECTRÓNICA] Extract taken from La Noche, independent free distribution magazine, based on Santiago Chile, May 17, 2010</ref> Since then, the scene has grown fast and massive events have taken place in many of Chile's major cities,<ref>[http://noticias.800.cl/archives/9155 Historia de la música electrónica en Chile] 800.cl Santiago, Chile, October 19, 2009</ref> including “C[C2] reamfields”, “Sensation White” (a spin-off from [[Amsterdam]]’s “Sensation”), and Ultra Music, an event that first appeared in [[Miami]].
In the last decade, techno and house music, mostly inspired by the movement in Berlin, has grown in Santiago. These underground scene has been recorded by labels like Comeme and Pirotecnia with stars from the scene like Alejandro Paz and Mamacita. <ref>[http://www2.latercera.com/noticia/el-underground-electronico-sale-a-luz/ El Underground Electrónico sale a la luz, La Tercera] </ref>
The [[International Society for Chilean Music (SIMUC)]] has a [[podcast]] called ''MEC''<ref>[http://www.simuc.org/sections/podcasts/mec/ MEC], a podcast on Chilean electronic music by the [[International Society for Chilean Music (SIMUC)]]</ref> dedicated exclusively to Chilean electronic music. The first episode was aired on September 30, 2016.
==Well-known artists== {{multiple image|direction=vertical | width = 130 | image1 = Villalobos at Fabric.jpg | caption1 = Villalobos at Fabric | image2 = Lucien N Luciano.jpg | caption2 = Lucien N Luciano also known as Luciano (2007) | image3 = Jorge Gonzalez.jpg | caption3 = Jorge Gonzalez, the leader and voice of [[Los Prisioneros]] | image4 = | caption4 = Nicolas Jaar }} * [[Ricardo Villalobos]]: Born in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]] and raised in [[Berlin]], Villalobos is well known for his work in the [[minimal techno]] and [[microhouse]] genres, and is one of the most significant figures in today's minimal techno scene.<ref>[http://www.ibiza-voice.com/music/artist/Ricardo_Villalobos Ricardo Villalobos] www.ibiza-voice.com Published by I Voice :: © 2003–2014 Retrieved on March 13, 2014</ref> * [[Andrés Bucci]]: One of the three Bucci brothers who are all well-known electronic music producers. Andrés began his career in 1996 while living in Germany, and the influence of the Berlin scene is noticeable in his work. He formed part of the group [[Plan V]], where he worked with [[Gustavo Ceratti]] ([[Soda Stereo]]), [[Christian Powditch]] and [[Guillermo Ugarte]], and also worked with [[Kate Simko]] in the duo Detalles.<ref>[http://www.ibiza-voice.com/music/artist/Andres_Bucci Andres Bucci] www.ibiza-voice.com Published by I Voice :: © 2003–2014 Retrieved on March 13, 2014</ref> * [[Cristian Vogel]]: Born in Chile, Vogel spentd a good part of his career living in [[Brighton]], [[England]] and is now based in Barcelona. Vogel is an important [[techno music|techno]] producer, although his experimental style goes beyond the usual standards of techno.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=459 Cristián Vogel.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508224520/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=459 |date=2014-05-08 }} musicapopular.cl David Ponce retrieved on March 14, 2014</ref> * [[Danieto]]: Danieto – real name Daniel Nieto – is a composer and engineer and one of the founders of the record label “Impar”. He is an experimental electronic musician known for his minimalistic, harmonious style.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1174 Danieto.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508230155/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1174 |date=2014-05-08 }} musicapopular.cl David Ponce retrieved on March 14, 2014</ref> * [[Latin Bitman]]: José Antonio Bravo, one half of the duo [[Bitman and Roban]] (a play on Batman and Robin), is a popular DJ, producer and composer of electronic music and funk. Latin Bitman is perhaps the most popular Chilean electronic artist outside Chile. He has a successful solo career and has collaborated with many other artists from different genres, such as [[Sen Dog]] and [[Eric_%22Bobo%22_Correa|Eric Bobo]] from [[Cypress Hill]], [[Francisca Valenzuela]] and [[Anita Tijoux]].<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1522 Latin Bitman.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426215335/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1522 |date=2014-04-26 }} musicapopular.cl David Ponce retrieved on March 14, 2014</ref> * [[Luciano (DJ)]]: Born Lucien Nicolet, Luciano has also been known as Lucien 'n' Luciano and DJ Magi-k during the 90s, and in Europe as Sense Club (in partnership with [[Ricardo Villalobos]]) and Monne Autumne (with [[Pier Bucci]] and [[Argenis Brito]]). Although he began DJing in Chile,<ref>[http://www.lucien-n-luciano.com/ lucien-n-luciano.com, official website] www.lucien-n-luciano.com Retrieved on March 15, 2014</ref> for most of his career he has been based in Germany and Switzerland, where he was born. His style combines [[techno]] and [[minimalist house]]. He is a permanent DJ at Geneva’s [[Weetamix]] and has played in many clubs around Europe.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1154 Luciano (Lucien Nicolet).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508230149/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1154 |date=2014-05-08 }} musicapopular.cl David Ponce retrieved on March 15, 2014</ref> * [[Alexi Delano]]: Born in Chile and raised in Sweden, with a career spanning more than two decades, Delano’s music strikes a balance between minimalist and dark techno. He has released five albums and numerous other records.<ref>[http://www.residentadvisor.net/dj/alexidelano/biography] residentadvisor.net retrieved on March 15, 2014</ref> * [[Pier Bucci]]: Born in Chile and based in Germany since 2002, Pier combines Latin rhythms with German electronic style. In the past, he has taken part in projects such as Skipsapiens with [[Danieto]], Monne Automne, Mambotur, [[Luciano]] (Lucien-n-Luciano) and [[Plan V]], with his brother Andrés. His first solo album, “Familia” (2005), included collaborations with Macha ([[Lafloripondio]]) and [[Armelle Pioline]] (Holden). His second album, “Amigo” (2010), featured [[Jorge González (musician)|Jorge González]] as well as Macha and Pioline.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=2844 Pier Bucci.] musicapopular.cl Marisol García retrieved on March 15, 2014</ref> * [[Chica Paula]]: Born in Santiago, DJ and producer Paula is currently based in Berlin and plays in the innovative musical collective Oceanclub[C3] and combines [[Ambient techno]] with house, techno and electro pop. She is the sister of producer [[Dandy Jack]] (Martín Schopf) and DJ Adrián (Adrián Schopf).<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1157 Chica Paula.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141029152742/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1157 |date=2014-10-29 }} musicapopular.cl David Ponce retrieved on March 17, 2014</ref> * [[Jorge González (musician)|Jorge González]]: Widely known as the vocalist of [[Los Prisioneros]], one of the most influential bands of Chile and Latin America,<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=21 Jorge Gonzalez.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426211028/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=21 |date=2014-04-26 }} musicapopular.cl Marisol García retrieved on March 17, 2014</ref> Gonzalez has experimented with electronic music since the beginning of his solo career and released his first album in partnership with [[Dandy Jack]] (Martín Schopf) under the moniker Gonzalo Martínez. The album, “Gonzalo Martínez y sus congas pensantes” (1997), was a mix of [[cumbia]] and [[techno]]. Later, Gonzalez formed “The Updates” with Loreto Otero, his then-wife, and released an album in 2008. The album’s mixture of house, pop, 2-step, 8-bit, funk and rave received strong reviews in the European specialist media.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1836 The Updates.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508223842/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1836 |date=2014-05-08 }} musicapopular.cl Marisol García retrieved on March 17, 2014</ref> * [[Nicolas Jaar]]: A Chilean-American musician, Jaar was also the founder of his own record label and art house[C4], [[Clown & Sunset]], and its successor “Other People”. Jaar's music is ruminative and emotional at only 100 [[Tempo|BPM C5]] (beats per minute) or less, far lower than the techno/house standards of 120–130 BPM. * [[Matias Aguayo]]: The youngest Chilean artist in the German electronic music scene, Aguayo mixes styles and genres as different as electronic, folk, reggae and country to create unique tracks.<ref>[http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature.aspx?1039 MAtias Aguayo in Residentadvisor] residentadvisor.net Philipp Cerfontaine, Published April 10, 2009 retrieved March 17, 2014</ref> His first release in 1998 was a 12” called "U.O.A.A. Shake it!", in collaboration with Michael Mayer, and since then Aguayo has released five albums and has collaborated with many other artists.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1612 Matias Aguayo.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508230152/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1612 |date=2014-05-08 }} musicapopular.cl Marisol García retrieved on March 17, 2014</ref> * [[Dandy Jack]] – real name Martín Schopf - was born in [[Santiago]] and lives in Germany. Many of his projects combine techno and Latin sounds and rhythms. Schopf is the other half of the Chilean duos Gonzalo Martinez, with [[Jorge González (musician)|Jorge González]], and “Ric Y Martin”, with [[Ricardo Villalobos]]. He is also part of the trio Sieg Über Die Sonne, with Lars Müller y Tobias Freund. Dandy Jack has released three original albums: “Dandy Jack and the Cosmic Trousers” (1996), “Dandy Jack and the Plastic Women” (1997) and “Los siete castigos” (2005), and has featured in more than 10 albums in collaboration with other musicians.<ref>[http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1157 Chica Paula.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141029152742/http://www.musicapopular.cl/3.0/index2.php?op=Artista&id=1157 |date=2014-10-29 }} musicapopular.cl David Ponce retrieved on March 17, 2014</ref>

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{more footnotes|date=February 2016}}{{more citations needed|date=February 2016}}}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox video game |title=Dance Dance Revolution SuperNOVA |image= Dance Dance Revolution SuperNova PS2.jpg |caption= North American PlayStation 2 version cover art |developer=[[Konami]] |publisher=Konami |series=''[[Dance Dance Revolution]]'' |released='''Arcade'''{{vgrelease|EU|April 28, 2006}}{{vgrelease|NA|May 15, 2006}}{{vgrelease|JP|July 12, 2006}}'''PlayStation 2'''{{vgrelease|NA|September 26, 2006}}{{vgrelease|JP|January 25, 2007}}{{vgrelease|EU|April 27, 2007}}'' |genre=[[Music video game|Music]], [[Exergaming|exercise]] |modes=[[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms=[[Arcade game|Arcade]], [[PlayStation 2]] |cabinet=Custom |arcade system=Bemani Python 2 |cpu=128 Bit [[Emotion Engine]] |sound=SPU2, CPU |display=29" flat [[Cathode ray tube|CRT]] ([[Raster graphics|Raster]], 740x480) }} {{nihongo|'''''Dance Dance Revolution SuperNova'''''|ダンスダンスレボリューションスーパーノヴァ|Dansu Dansu Reboryūshon Sūpānova}}, released in Europe as '''''Dancing Stage SuperNova''''', is an arcade and [[PlayStation 2]] game in the ''[[Dance Dance Revolution]]'' (''DDR'') series of [[music video game]]s. It was produced by [[Konami]] and released through Betson Enterprises. The game was released in Europe on April 28, 2006, followed shortly by a North American release on May 15 and a Japanese release on July 12. Unlike previous ''DDR'' arcade releases, all versions have the same features and song list. It is the 5th arcade release in Europe, the 3rd arcade release in North America, and the 9th arcade release in Japan.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} ==Features== ===Characters=== ''SuperNova'' reintroduces characters, after their absence from ''[[DDRMAX Dance Dance Revolution 6thMix|DDRMAX]]'' games and ''[[Dance Dance Revolution Extreme]]''. In ''SuperNova'', character selection is random by default, but can be changed in the options menu. The following eight characters are available: {{div col}} * Afro * Baby-Lon * Emi * Gus (new) * Rage * Jenny * Robo-Zukin (new) * Ruby (new) {{div col end}} ''SuperNova 2'' retains these characters while adding six new characters and a dedicated character selection screen, for a total of 14 characters. Three of the new characters (Alice, Julio and Yuni) and all returning characters, with the exception of Robo-Zukin, also receive a second costume, for a total of 23 costumes. The following new characters are available: {{div col}} * Alice * Dark-Zukin * Concent Be-fU * Concent Kyo-fU * Julio * Yuni {{div col end}} Of the 14 characters, 10 return in ''[[Dance Dance Revolution A]]''. The Concent and Zukin pairs are unavailable. ===e-Amusement=== The game supported [[e-Amusement]] functionality in Asia, with limited testing outside of Asia. ===Link Data (cancelled)=== Link Data was a planned feature for the ''Dance Dance Revolution SuperNova'' series designed to provide connectivity between the arcade and [[PlayStation 2]] versions of the game, by means of a PlayStation 2 [[memory card]]. The reader was depicted in arcade flyers, but it was never released. This feature already existed in ''[[Dance Dance Revolution Extreme]]'' and several earlier releases, but used [[PlayStation (console)|original PlayStation]] memory cards and readers instead, which ''SuperNova'' does not support. Supplier issues with Sony forced Konami to cancel the functionality. To compensate, Konami offered a coupon or soundtrack sampler for customers in [[North America]] who purchased the game in 2006.{{cite web |author1=Konami America |title=Arcade Linking Function |url=http://www.konami.com:80/edealinv/servlet/ExecMacro?nurl=control/Support.vm&ctl_nbr=3810 |accessdate=July 12, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061217142714/http://www.konami.com/edealinv/servlet/ExecMacro?nurl=control%2FSupport.vm&ctl_nbr=3810 |archivedate=December 17, 2006 |date=December 17, 2006 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }} ==Release== The game was released in North America on May 15, 2006, with the first confirmed sighting at [[Disneyland]] in [[Anaheim, California]] at the [[Tomorrowland]] Starcade. Its release in Japan was delayed slightly so that the game software could be updated to fix the reported timing issues, and was later released with an extra song (the aforementioned remix of Flow) in late July 2006.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} ==Music== {{Main|Music of Dance Dance Revolution SuperNova}} The arcade release of ''SuperNova'' contains 304 songs, of which 120 are all-new additions to the game. The arcade release of ''SuperNova 2'' contains 357 songs, of which 62 are all-new additions to the game. {{Hidden begin|toggle=left|title=''DDR SuperNOVA 2'' Arcade soundtrack}} {|class="wikitable sortable" !style="background:#fff;"|Song !style="background:#fff;"|Artist !style="background:#fff;"|Note |- !colspan="3" style="background:#ffffff;"|Licensed songs (14 total) |-style="background:#ffff88;" |"[[Ain't No Mountain High Enough|AIN'T NO MOUNTAIN HIGH ENOUGH]]" |SLOTH MUSIC PROJECT feat.
