A passage in an old play by [[Robert Greene (dramatist)|Robert Greene]] has been quoted by several writers as evidence that primero was a gambling game."Primero, why I though[t] thou hadst not been so much gamester as play at it" - Greene's: (1611) ''Tu Quoque'' But a person who objects to cards, might make such a remark with respect to any card game, whether a gambling game or not. Judging from the partial descriptions of the game which remain to us, it might seem that primero was played for either large or small stakes, as agreed upon. [[John Florio]] describes primero played by two persons for "one shilling stake and three rest (pool)."Florio's ''Second Frutes'' (1591) In Minsheu's "Spanish Dialogues", four play; the stake is two shillings and the rest, eight.''Once a Week'', vol. 10; Eneas Sweetland Dallas; London: Bradbury and Evans, 1863; p. 363. The text is self-explanatory, explaining also the meaning of the name primero.[[John Minsheu]], ''Spanish Dialogues'' (long title: ''Pleasant and Delightful Dialgues in Spanish and English''); London: John Haviland, 1623; p. 26. Quote: "I take it that it is called ''primero'', because it hath the first place at the play at cardes." See any online copy for the full dialogue of the gamers as they play, e.g. [http://jducoeur.org/game-hist/primero-dialogue.html this excerpt] of the passage in question. == Primero and the Tudor dynasty == Primero appears to have been one of the earliest card games played in England during the Renaissance and the [[Tudor dynasty]],''A glossary: or, Collection of words, phrases, names, etc.'' v. II pg. 687, Robert Nares, London (1859) and certainly it continued to be one of the most fashionable games throughout the reigns of [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]], [[Edward VI]], [[Mary I of England]], [[Elizabeth I]] and [[James I of England|James I]], due to the frequent mention of it by many writers of that time. Already during the reign of Henry VII, notices of money issued several times for the King's losses at cards appear in the Remembrance's Office, dated December the 26th, in the ninth year of his reign. There, an entry is made of one hundred shillings paid at one time to him for the purpose of playing at cards. The private expenses of Princess Mary, Henry VIII's daughter and later Queen, also contain numerous items of money "for the playe at cardes". But despite the records, it is not certain that primero found its way to England previously to the marriage of Queen Mary I with [[Philip II of Spain]], although there is no doubt that his coming to England from the court of Charles V would have cause it to be more generally known and played. [[William Shakespeare]] also speaks of Henry VIII playing at primero with his brother-in-law [[Charles Brandon, 1st Duke of Suffolk]], and makes [[Falstaff]] say: "I never prospered since I forswore myself at primero." Additionally, the clown Lancelot in Shakespeare's ''The Merchant of Venice'' confides in this father that "for mine own part, as I have set up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I have sun some ground" (2.2.91-92). To "set up [one's] rest" alludes to a type of gamble in the Italian version of primero {{see below|lc=y|short=y}}. Among the epigrams of [[John Harington (writer)|John Harington]] we have one which describes "The Story of Marcus' Life at Primero","The Story of Marcus' Life at Primero", in ''Old English Plays'', Fourth Ed., Vol. IX; ed. W. Carew Hazlitt; London: Reeves and Turner; 1874 (reprint of 1744 original publications by Robert Dodsley).
{{quote|1=Fond Marcus ever at Primero playes, Long winter nights, and as long Summer dayes: And I heard once, to idle talke attending; The Story of his times, and coines mis-spending. ... }} See [https://books.google.com/books?id=ymZHAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA387&lpg=PA387&dq="Long+winter+nights,+and+as+long+Summer+dayes"&source=bl&ots=JeGt0iJzqD&sig=WjfOYKftSYgU3Da4_NwEfYNLKmc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo5MbH9vvLAhVKx2MKHcWwDq0Q6AEIKTAE#v=onepage&q=%22Long%20winter%20nights%2C%20and%20as%20long%20Summer%20dayes%22&f=false Google Books scan] for the full text. in which many of the terms of the game are developed in detail. == Evolution and decline == Judging by the pattern of succession of games during the Renaissance, it is to be noted that many of the card games played throughout Europe, ascended in popularity to be later replaced by another type of game, again brought into England by the court gamester of that time. So that, by the last quarter of the 16th century, primero had already decreased in popularity, and was gradually replaced by the [[trick-taking game]] [[Spoil Five|maw]], the favorite card game of James I, and alluded by Harington as supplanting primero. According to [[Charles Cotton]],''Cotton's Complete Gamester'', ed. of 1721, pg. 49 primero, which by the time of the Restoration in 1660 had already evolved into many other variations, some of six cards, rapidly went out of fashion with the introduction of the Spanish game of [[Ombre]]. == Rules of the game == The object of the game, as in poker, is to attain the highest possible hand, or at least bluff your competitors out of betting against you. There are no existing written rules for the 16th-century primero, only descriptions. However, a number of reconstructions of the game have been made, primarily on the basis of books describing playing strategy and references in period literature. === The play === Primero is played with a 40-card deck, and there are special decks made for this game. It works best with four to six players. The player who holds the ''prime'', a sequence of the best cards and a good trump, is sure to be successful over the adversaries – hence the game's name. {| class="wikitable" |+ '''Primero hands from high to low''' |----- | '''Chorus''' (quartet)|| align="left" | Four cards of a kind |----- | '''Fluxus''' (flush)|| align="left" | All cards of the same suit |----- | '''Supremus''' (fifty-five)|| align="left" | The highest possible three-flush, the ace, 6, 7 (plus an unrelated fourth card) and ace card from any other suit. |----- | '''Primero ''' (prime)|| align="left" | One card from each suit. It's a four-card hand containing one card of each suit, hence the exact opposite of a flush in poker. |----- | '''Numerus''' (point)|| align="left" | Two or three cards of the same suit. A point of higher card-value beats one of lower value for which purpose Courts count 10 each of the hand is the sum of the cards. ace, 6, 7 and jack cards in any suit. |}
[[File:Card Players Lucas van Leyden, 1525..jpg|thumb|250px|''Card Players'' by Lucas van Leyden.
It is assumed that the subject of this painting may not be the obvious three card players, but in fact it may refer to a secret political alliance between Spain and England against Francis I of France. The figure on the left would be Charles V and on the right Cardinal Wolsey, both entering into a secret agreement. The woman in the centre would be Margaret of Austria, sister of Charles V and regent of the Netherlands.]] {| class="wikitable" |+ '''Card point values''' |----- | Type of card || align="left" | Value |----- | '''Any [[Face card|Face (court) card]]'''|| align="left" | 10 points |----- | '''2 ''' (deuce)|| align="left" | 12 points |----- | '''3 ''' (trey)|| align="left" | 13 points |----- | '''4 ''' || align="left" | 14 points |----- | '''5 ''' || align="left" | 15 points |----- | '''Ace''' || align="left" | 16 points |----- | '''6''' || align="left" | 18 points |----- | '''7''' || align="left" | 21 points |} === English version === Because this is a gambling game, the first step is for all players to ante into the pot. The deal is counter-clockwise, starting with the dealer. Each player receives 4 cards dealt in 2's from a 40-card deck ranking K Q J 7 6 5 4 3 2 A. Anyone dealt a winning combination calls for an immediate showdown, and the player with the best hand wins the pot. Two cards go to each player, which is followed by the next phase of betting, and two more cards are dealt to each player. Then either eight cards are dealt face down on the table and the remaining cards are left out as a draw or stock pile. Alternatively, eight cards are laid out on the table and players may draw and discard from only these. When a player is satisfied with his cards, he may knock on the table, calling out: ''Vada'' (go!), which brings an immediate showdown won by the best hand. If no one bets, the stakes are carried forward to the next deal; but if one stays in, at least one other must contest the pot, this obligation ultimately falling upon the player immediately ahead of the last bettor if everyone else has folded. In a showdown, the better equal combinations are those with the highest point. Thus, a quartet of aces (4x16=64) beats a quartet of 5s (60), but it's beaten by four 6s (72). Four kings will not beat four queens or jacks, as these hands all count 40. Such ties are broken in favor of the [[eldest hand]] competing. Players ''vie'' or ''vye'' by stating how high a hand they are claiming to have, and may ''bluff'' by overstating it. What they apparently must not do is to underbid their hands; for as Cardano puts it: "If anyone wins with the greatest point, he is obliged to show another card; otherwise he loses his deposit because he could have a 'Flush'... Similarly, if he 'vies' on the basis of point, he is obliged to show two different cards and one of a matching suit, so that no one may suspect him of having a 'Flush' or 'Prime'."''King Henry VIII - All is true.'' John Fletcher, Gordan McMullan, pg. 437 – The Arden Shakespeare 2000 {{ISBN|1-903436-25-7}} A player may either knock or draw in a turn, but not both. Once a player knocks, he may no longer draw. When two players have knocked, the play stops, and cards are shown. Betting starts after the two cards are dealt, and may continue after these two cards have been dealt, and then at every round, just before the dealer's turn. The dealer always bets first. Players may match, raise, or fold any time during wagering. If all players refuse a bet, it must be withdrawn. === Italian version === In Rome, the full 52-card deck was used.Zorli, Girolamo. [http://www.tretre.it/menu/accademia-del-tre/documenti-e-articoli/francesco-bernis-primero/ Francesco Berni's Primero] at TreTre. Retrieved 7 March 2017. In Florence, it is custom to leave out the 7s, 8s and 9s, keeping and vying only with the smaller cards; the "rest" (''to set up a rest'' means 'to win [something]', and is a phrase which occurs in almost every poem in the times of James and Charles. It is taken from terms used at primero, and perhaps other games then played)''Supposes'', by Gascoigne, A.3 S.2 is made at the second card, and when the first player say "pass", every one is obliged to discard, notwithstanding any one may have an ace or a 6 in hand. In Venice, for instance, the mode of playing may be different; in Lombardy, Naples, France and Spain, so many countries, so many customs. But of all the modes, none can be superior to that of the court of Rome. There, the 7s, 8s and 9s are not withdrawn; there it is allowed to discard, but not both cards after "pass" is once said; nor can this be done with the two cards of the ''rest'', as it is usual in other places. The most essential operation of this game may be its two principal hands, the ''flush''{{clarify|date=April 2016|reason=What is the Italian term? Don't switch back and forth between the languages randomly.}} and the ''{{lang|it|primera}}'', and a third, derived from the first, which is called ''{{lang|it|punto}}''; from these three are deducted all the varieties which daily occur at primero, as the greater and lesser ''flush'', the great and little ''prime'', and more or less points; this diversity gives rise to numerous controversies and disputable points. Another excellent hand in this game is four-of-a-kind; four court cards, four aces, etc., beat both the flush and ''{{lang|it|primera}}. === Spanish version === [[Jacob Le Duchat]], in a note on that chapter of Rabelais,''Oeuvres de Rabelais avec les remarques de Duchat'', T. 1, pg. 78, 4 to. Amst. 1741 in which the games Gargantua played at are enumerated, has described the mode of playing primero, and a similar account may be gathered from the ''Dictionary of the Spanish Academy.'' According to Duchat, there are two kinds of primero, the greater and the lesser; the difference between them is that the former is played with the figured cards, while at the latter the highest card is the 7, which counts for 21. Each player has four cards, which are dealt one by one. the next card in value to the 7 is the 6, which counts for 18; then the 6, which counts for 15. The ace is equivalent to 6 points, but the 2 (deuce), the 3 (trey) and the 4 count only for their respective numbers. To these cards may be added, if the players choose, the ''{{lang|es|quinola}}'', for which the jack of hearts is most commonly chosen, and of which he may make what card and what colour he likes. After which each of the players show their four cards, and he whose cards are all of different sorts wins the prime, if they are all of one colour he wins the Flush. Meanwhile, according to the ''Great Spanish Dictionary'', is played by dealing four cards to each player; the value of the 7, 6 and ace, are the same; but the 2 is said to count for 12, the 3 for 13, the 4 for 14, and the 5 for 15, the figured cards are each equivalent to 10. The best hand is the flush, that is, four cards of high numbers and one of one colour; the next is the ''{{lang|es|punto}}''(supremus), consisting of the ''{{lang|es|quinola}}', 7, 6, and ace, which count for 55; then the {{lang|es|primera}}, or prime, which is four cards of different suits. Should two persons have flushes, the player who counts the highest number, or the greatest flush wins, and the same regulation holds good in regard to the prime. But should there be neither flush nor prime, the one who can count the most points in one suit wins.''Dicionario de la Lengua Castellana para la Real Academia in voce Primiera'', pg. 563. Ed. 1856 ==See also== *[[Gilet (card game)|Gilet]] *[[Put (card game)]] *[[Bouillotte]] *[[Post and pair]] *[[Ambigu]] *[[Brelan]] *[[Three-card brag]] ==References== {{reflist|29em}} {{refbegin}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=6LQ4-wUOrlgC&pg=PA91&dq=the+game+of++primero&lr=&hl=cs#v=onepage&q=&f=false "Primero"] in ''Sports and Games of the Renaissance'', Andrew Leibs; London: Greenwood Press, 2004; pp. 91–92 {{refend}} ==External links== {{wiktionary}} *[http://jducoeur.org/game-hist/game-recon-primero.html Game Report: "Primero – Reconstructed from primary and tertiary sources"], Justin du Coeur, 2003 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091026162855/http://geocities.com/jeff_suzuki/primero.html "Primero: A Renaissance Cardgame"], Jeff A. Suzuki, 2007; another reconstruction of the game [[Category:16th-century card games]] [[Category:Comparing card games]] [[Category:Gambling games]]

revision.comment: /* Critical response */ Updated Rotten Tomatoes figures
revision.text:
{{about|the film|other uses|Quantum of Solace (disambiguation)}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{EngvarB|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox film |name = Quantum of Solace |image = Quantum of Solace - UK cinema poster.jpg |alt = Empire Design's poster for ''Quantum of Solace'' |caption = British cinema poster | director = [[Marc Forster]] | producer = {{plainlist | *[[Michael G. Wilson]] *[[Barbara Broccoli]]}} | writer = {{plainlist | *[[Paul Haggis]] *[[Neal Purvis and Robert Wade|Neal Purvis]] *[[Neal Purvis and Robert Wade|Robert Wade]]}} | based on = {{Based on|''[[James Bond (literary character)|James Bond]]''|[[Ian Fleming]]}} |starring = {{plainlist | *[[Daniel Craig]] *[[Olga Kurylenko]] *[[Mathieu Amalric]] *[[Gemma Arterton]] *[[Giancarlo Giannini]] *[[Jeffrey Wright (actor)|Jeffrey Wright]] *[[Judi Dench]] }} | music = [[David Arnold]] | cinematography = [[Roberto Schaefer]] | editing = {{plainlist | *[[Matt Chesse]] *[[Richard Pearson (film editor)|Rick Pearson]]}} | studio = [[Eon Productions]]
[[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | distributor = [[Sony Pictures Releasing]]https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/64729?sid=b7c9f0f6-6e18-402f-b725-a18e455f6bfc&sr=3.7816277&cp=1&pos=0 | released = {{Film date|df=y|2008|10|29|London premiere|2008|10|31|United Kingdom|2008|11|14|United States}} | runtime = 106 minutes | country = {{plainlist| * United Kingdom{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b8bf92120|title=Quantum of Solace (2008)|work=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=29 May 2016}} * United States }} | language = English | budget = $200 million | gross = $586.1 million{{cite web|title=Quantum of Solace (2008)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jamesbond22.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=3 November 2012}} }} '''''Quantum of Solace''''' is a 2008 British [[spy film]], the twenty-second in the [[James Bond in film|''James Bond'' series]] produced by [[Eon Productions]], directed by [[Marc Forster]] and written by [[Paul Haggis]], [[Neal Purvis and Robert Wade]]. It is the second film to star [[Daniel Craig]] as the fictional [[MI6]] agent [[James Bond]]. The film also stars [[Olga Kurylenko]], [[Mathieu Amalric]], [[Gemma Arterton]], [[Jeffrey Wright (actor)|Jeffrey Wright]], and [[Judi Dench]]. In the film, Bond seeks revenge for the death of his lover, [[Vesper Lynd]], and is assisted by [[Camille Montes]], who is plotting revenge for the murder of her own family. The trail eventually leads them to wealthy businessman [[Dominic Greene]], a member of the [[Quantum (James Bond)|Quantum]] organisation, who intends to stage a ''[[coup d'état]]'' in Bolivia to [[Water privatization in Bolivia|seize control of their water supply]]. Producer [[Michael G. Wilson]] developed the film's plot while the previous film in the series, [[Casino Royale (2006 film)|''Casino Royale'']], was being shot. Purvis, Wade, and Haggis contributed to the script. Craig and Forster had to write some sections themselves due to the [[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike|Writers' Strike]], though they were not given the screenwriter credit in the final cut. The title was chosen from a 1959 short story in [[Ian Fleming]]'s ''[[For Your Eyes Only (short story collection)|For Your Eyes Only]]'', though the film does not contain any elements of that story. Location filming took place in Mexico, Panama, Chile, Italy, Austria and Wales, while interior sets were built and filmed at [[Pinewood Studios]]. Forster aimed to make a modern film that also featured classic cinema motifs: a vintage [[Douglas DC-3]] was used for a flight sequence, and [[Dennis Gassner]]'s set designs are reminiscent of [[Ken Adam]]'s work on several early ''Bond'' films. Taking a course away from the usual [[List of James Bond villains|Bond villains]], Forster rejected any grotesque appearance for the character Dominic Greene to emphasise the hidden and secret nature of the film's contemporary villains. The film was also marked by its frequent depictions of violence, with a 2012 study by the [[University of Otago]] in New Zealand finding it to be the most violent film in the franchise. Whereas ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr. No]]'' featured 109 "trivial or severely violent" acts, ''Quantum of Solace'' had a count of 250—the most depictions of violence in any ''Bond'' film—even more prominent since it was also the shortest film in the franchise.{{cite news|url=http://www.meeja.com.au/2012/sean-connery-was-the-girliest-bond/|title=Sean Connery was the girliest Bond|publisher=Meeja|date=10 December 2012|accessdate=6 September 2011|location=Australia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130108212058/http://meeja.com.au/2012/sean-connery-was-the-girliest-bond/|archivedate=8 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} ''Quantum of Solace'' premiered at the [[Odeon Leicester Square]] on 29 October 2008, gathering mixed reviews, which mainly praised Craig's gritty performance and the film's action sequences, but felt that the film was less impressive than its predecessor ''Casino Royale''. {{As of|2016|September}}, it is the fourth-highest-grossing ''James Bond'' film, without adjusting for inflation, earning $586 million worldwide, and becoming the [[2008 in film#Highest-grossing films|seventh highest-grossing film of 2008]]. ==Plot== James Bond is driving from [[Lake Garda]] to [[Siena]], Italy, with the captured [[List of James Bond villains#Casino Royale 2006|Mr. White]] ([[Jesper Christensen]]) in the [[Trunk (automobile)|boot]] of [[Aston Martin DBS V12|his car]]. After evading pursuers, Bond delivers White to [[M (James Bond)|M]], who interrogates him regarding his organisation, [[SPECTRE#Rebooted continuity|Quantum]]. M's [[bodyguard]], Craig Mitchell (Glenn Foster), is a [[double agent]]; he attacks M, enabling White to escape. Bond chases Mitchell and kills him. Bond and M return to London and search Mitchell's flat, discovering Mitchell had a contact in [[Haiti]], Edmund Slate ([[Neil Jackson]]). Bond learns Slate is a hitman sent to kill [[Camille Montes]] ([[Olga Kurylenko]]) at the behest of her lover, environmentalist entrepreneur [[List of James Bond villains#Quantum of Solace|Dominic Greene]] ([[Mathieu Amalric]]). Observing her subsequent meeting with Greene, Bond learns Greene is helping exiled Bolivian General Medrano ([[Joaquín Cosío]]), who murdered Camille's family, to overthrow his government and become the new president, in exchange for a seemingly barren piece of desert. After rescuing Camille from Medrano, Bond follows Greene to a performance of ''[[Tosca]]'' in [[Bregenz]], Austria. Meanwhile, the head of the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]]'s South American section, Gregg Beam ([[David Harbour]]), strikes a noninterference deal with Greene for access to putative stocks of Bolivian oil. Bond infiltrates Quantum's meeting at the opera, identifying members of Quantum's executive board, and a gunfight ensues. A [[Counter Terrorism Command|Special Branch]] bodyguard working for Quantum member Guy Haines ([[Paul Ritter (actor)|Paul Ritter]]), is killed by one of Greene's men after Bond throws him off a roof. M assumes Bond killed him, and has Bond's passports and credit cards revoked. Bond heads to Italy and convinces his old ally [[List of James Bond allies#René Mathis|René Mathis]] ([[Giancarlo Giannini]]) to accompany him to Bolivia. They are greeted by Strawberry Fields ([[Gemma Arterton]]), a consular employee who demands Bond return to the UK immediately. Bond seduces her and they attend a fundraising party Greene holds that night. At the party, Bond again rescues Camille from Greene. Leaving, Bond and Camille are pulled over by Bolivian police working for Medrano. They had earlier attacked Mathis and put him in the boot of Bond's car to frame Bond. In the ensuing struggle, Mathis and the cops are killed. The following day, Bond and Camille survey Quantum's intended land acquisition by air; their plane is shot down by a Bolivian fighter aircraft. They [[skydive]] into a [[sinkhole]], and discover Quantum is damming Bolivia's supply of fresh water to create a [[monopoly]]. Back in La Paz, Bond meets M and learns Quantum killed Fields by drowning her in [[Petroleum|crude oil]]. Bond meets CIA Agent [[Felix Leiter]] ([[Jeffrey Wright (actor)|Jeffrey Wright]]), who discloses Greene and Medrano will meet in the [[Atacama Desert]] to finalise their agreement. Warned by Leiter, he evades the CIA's [[Special Activities Division]] when they attempt to kill him. At an [[eco hotel]] in the desert, Greene tells Medrano that now he controls the majority of Bolivia's water supply, Medrano must accept a new contract that makes Greene Planet Bolivia's sole water [[utility company]] at significantly higher rates. Bond infiltrates the complex, kills the chief of police ([[Fernando Guillén Cuervo]]) for betraying Mathis, and single-handedly assaults the hotel. After killing the security detail, he confronts Greene. Meanwhile, Camille kills Medrano, avenging the murders of her family. The struggle leaves the hotel destroyed by fire. Bond captures Greene and interrogates him about Quantum, leaving him stranded in the desert with only a can of engine oil, wondering if Greene will get thirsty enough to drink it. Bond travels to [[Kazan]], Russia, where he finds [[Vesper Lynd]]'s former lover, Yusef Kabira ([[Simon Kassianides]]), a member of Quantum who seduces women with valuable connections, and who is indirectly responsible for her death. Bond tells Kabira's latest target, Corrine Veneau ([[Stana Katic]]), a [[Canadian Security Intelligence Service|Canadian Intelligence]] agent, of Kabira's true intentions, thus sparing her Vesper's fate. He allows MI6 to arrest Kabira. Outside, M tells Bond that Greene was found dead in the middle of the desert, shot twice and with engine oil in his stomach. M tells Bond she needs him back; he responds that he never left. Walking away, he drops Vesper's necklace in the snow. ==Cast== * [[Daniel Craig]] as [[James Bond filmography|James Bond]]. Craig's physical training for his reprise of the role placed extra effort into running and boxing, to spare him the injuries he sustained on his stunts in the first film.{{cite news |author=Martyn Palmer |title=The man with the golden touch |work=[[The Times]] |date=24 November 2007|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article2900516.ece?token=null&offset=0 |accessdate=25 November 2007 | location=London}} Craig felt he was fitter, being less bulky than in the first film. He also practised speedboating and stunt driving. Craig felt ''Casino Royale'' was [physically] "a walk in the park" compared to ''Quantum of Solace'',{{cite web | title = Newswrap | publisher = Official site | format= Flash video | url = http://www.007.com/ | accessdate=1 March 2008}} which required a different performance from him because ''Quantum of Solace'' is a revenge film, not a love story like ''Casino Royale''. While filming in Pinewood, he suffered a gash when kicked in his face,{{cite news|author=Benjamin Svetkey|title=Bond is back!|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=30 October 2008|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20237005,00.html|accessdate=1 November 2008}} which required eight stitches, and a fingertip was sliced off. He laughed these off, noting they did not delay filming, and joked his finger wound would enable him to have a criminal career (though it had grown back when he made this comment).{{cite news|author=John Naughton|title=Spy Harder|work=[[GQ (magazine)|GQ]]|date=November 2008|pages=278–335}} He also had minor plastic surgery on his face.{{cite news|title=Bond actor admits plastic surgery|publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=9 October 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7660808.stm|accessdate=12 October 2008}} The actor advised Paul Haggis on the script and helped choose [[Marc Forster]] as the director.{{cite news |author=Jennifer Vineyard |title=Daniel Craig Says He's Feeling The 'Pressure' Of James Bond Follow-Up |publisher=MTV |date=6 December 2007 |url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1575858/20071205/story.jhtml |accessdate=7 December 2007}} * [[Olga Kurylenko]] as [[Camille Montes]], a Bolivian agent with her own vendetta regarding Greene and Medrano. Forster chose her because out of the 400 women who auditioned, she seemed the least nervous.{{cite news|author=Matt Mueller|title=On the Set of 'Quantum Of Solace': Olga Kurylenko: The Bond Girl|work=[[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]]|url=http://www.premiere.com/Feature/On-the-Set-of-Quantum-Of-Solace/On-the-Set-of-Quantum-Of-Solace2|accessdate=14 January 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100113010442/http://www.premiere.com/Feature/On-the-Set-of-Quantum-Of-Solace/On-the-Set-of-Quantum-Of-Solace2|archivedate=13 January 2010}} When she read the script, she was glad she had no love scene with Craig; she felt it would have distracted viewers from her performance.{{cite news|author=Tim Masters|title=Talking Shop: Olga Kurylenko|publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=31 October 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7695332.stm|accessdate=31 October 2008}} Kurylenko spent three weeks training to fight with weapons, and she learnt a form of indoor skydiving known as body flying. Kurylenko said she had to do "training non-stop from the morning to the evening" for the action scenes, overcoming her fears with the help of Craig and the stunt team.{{cite web|title = Chile Soundbites videos|publisher = Sony [[Electronic Press Kit]]|url = http://sony.epk.tv/campaign/quantum-of-solace|accessdate=11 April 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/film/article1003382.ece|title=Street urchin to Bond girl |work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] |last=Hollins|first=Grant|date=5 April 2008|accessdate=6 September 2011|location=London}} She was given a DVD box set of Bond films, since the franchise was not easily available to watch in her native Ukraine. Kurylenko found [[Michelle Yeoh]] in ''[[Tomorrow Never Dies]]'' inspiring "because she did the fight scenes by herself." The producers had intended to cast a South American actress in the role. Kurylenko trained with a [[dialect coach]] to perform with a Spanish accent.{{cite news|author = Chris Tilly|title = Olga Kurylenko Q&A|publisher = [[IGN]]|date = 31 January 2008|url = http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/848/848813p1.html|accessdate = 31 January 2008|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080204085248/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/848/848813p1.html|archivedate = 4 February 2008|df = dmy-all}} She said that the accent was easy for her because she has "a lot of hispanic friends, from Latin America and Spain, and it's an accent I've always heard".{{cite news|author = Rob Scheer|title = INTERVIEW: Olga Kurylenko on "Quantum of Solace"|publisher = [[UGO]]|date = 14 November 2008|url = http://www.cinecon.com/news/1825/interview-olga-kurylenko-quantum-of-solace/|accessdate=6 September 2011}} When reflecting on her experience as a [[Bond girl]], she stated she was proudest of overcoming her fears in performing stunts.{{cite news|author=David Giammarco|title=From Ukraine, with love|work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]|url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/features/features/display.var.2446992.0.From_Ukraine_with_love.php|accessdate=18 September 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903045044/http://www.theherald.co.uk/features/features/display.var.2446992.0.From_Ukraine_with_love.php|archivedate=3 September 2009}} * [[Mathieu Amalric]] as [[List of James Bond villains#Quantum of Solace|Dominic Greene]], the main villain. He is a leading member of Quantum posing as a businessman working in [[reforestation]] and charity funding for environmental science. In the 2015 Bond film ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'', he is revealed to have been a member of the [[SPECTRE|titular crime syndicate]], of which Quantum is a subsidiary. Amalric acknowledged taking the role was an easy decision because, "It's impossible to say to your kids that 'I could have been in a Bond film but I refused.'" Amalric wanted to wear make-up for the role, but Forster explained that he wanted Greene not to look grotesque, but to symbolise the hidden evils in society. Amalric modelled his performance on "the smile of [[Tony Blair]] [and] the craziness of [[Nicolas Sarkozy|Sarkozy]]," the latter of whom he called "the worst villain we [the French] have ever had … he walks around thinking he's in a Bond film."{{cite news | title = Bond villain spills the beans | work = [[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] | date = 24 January 2008 | url = http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/85747-bond-villain-spills-the-beans | accessdate=31 January 2008}} He later claimed this was not criticism of either politician, but rather an example of how a politician relies on performance instead of a genuine policy to win power. "Sarkozy, is just a better actor than [his presidential opponent] [[Ségolène Royal]]—that's all," he explained. Amalric and Forster reconceived the character, who was supposed to have a "special skill" in the script, to someone who uses pure animal instinct when fighting Bond in the climax.{{cite news|title=Quantum of Solace: Mathieu Amalric on playing James Bond's nemesis|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2 October 2008|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2008/10/23/sm_mathieuamalric.xml|accessdate=23 October 2008|location=London|first=Murphy|last=Williams}} [[Bruno Ganz]] was also considered for the part,{{cite news |title=Bond 22 Pre-Production Diary (22)|publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]] |date=30 December 2007 |url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_preprod_diary22.php3?t=&s=articles |accessdate=31 December 2007}} but Forster decided Amalric gave the character a "pitiful" quality. * [[Judi Dench]] as M. Forster felt Dench was underused in the previous films and wanted to make her part bigger, having her interact with Bond more because she is "the only woman Bond doesn't see in a sexual context," which Forster finds interesting.{{cite news|title=Fostering change|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=11 October 2008|url=http://www.star-ecentral.com/news/story.asp?file=/2008/10/11/movies/2202154&sec=movies|accessdate=13 October 2008}} * [[Gemma Arterton]] as MI6 agent Strawberry Fields, who works at the British consulate in Bolivia. Fields, who is merely an office worker as described by M, takes herself seriously and tries to overpower Bond when the pair meet. She is later seduced by Bond, infiltrates Greene's fund raiser party with him and ends up paying the ultimate price. Forster found Arterton a witty actress and selected her from a reported 1,500 candidates. One of the casting directors asked her to audition for the role, having seen her portray Rosaline in ''[[Love's Labour's Lost]]'' at the [[Globe Theatre]].{{cite news | author = Chris Tilly | title = Gemma Arteron Q&A | publisher = [[IGN]] | date = 30 January 2008 | url = http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/848/848237p1.html | accessdate = 30 January 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080201171744/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/848/848237p1.html | archivedate = 1 February 2008 | df = dmy-all }} Arterton said Fields was "not so frolicsome" as other Bond girls, but is instead "fresh and young, not … a [[femme fatale]]." Arterton described Fields as a homage to the 1960s Bond girls, comparing her red wig to that of [[Diana Rigg]], who played [[Tracy Bond]] in ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]''. Rigg, alongside [[Honor Blackman]], is one of her favourite Bond girls. Arterton had to film her character's death scene first day on the set, where she was completely covered head to toe in non-toxic black paint. Although she found the experience unpleasant, she believed the scene would be an iconic part of the film.{{cite news |title=SPOILER ALERT - Oilfinger: Exclusive picture shows Gemma Arterton coming to a sticky end in new Bond film|author=Harper, Tom|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=6 October 2008 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1068483/SPOILER-ALERT.html|accessdate=2 May 2009}} The character's full name, which is a reference to [[the Beatles]] song "[[Strawberry Fields Forever]]", is never actually uttered on screen; when Bond asks her for her name, she replies, "Just Fields." Robert A. Caplen suggests that this is a conscious effort to portray a woman "whose character attributes are neither undermined nor compromised" by her name, even though her name may have sexual overtones reminiscent of earlier [[Bond girls]].{{cite book|last=Caplen|first=Robert A.|title=Shaken & Stirred: The Feminism of James Bond|year=2010|page=346|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y8p-qpJjPU4C&pg=PA346|isbn=978-1-4535-1282-1}} In August 2018, Arterton wrote a short story titled ''Woke Bond Woman'', based on the character.{{cite web|url=https://www.timesnownews.com/entertainment/news/international-news/article/gemma-arterton-pens-a-short-story-about-her-bond-character/268793|title=Gemma Arterton pens a short story about her Bond character|publisher=''Times Now News''|date=13 August 2018|accessdate=10 November 2018}} * [[Giancarlo Giannini]] as [[René Mathis]], Bond's ally who was mistakenly believed to be a traitor in ''Casino Royale''. Having been acquitted, he chooses to aid Bond again in his quest to find out who betrayed him. * [[Jeffrey Wright (actor)|Jeffrey Wright]] as [[Felix Leiter]], Bond's ally at the CIA. Early script drafts gave Leiter a larger role, but his screentime was restricted by on-set rewrites.{{cite news|title=The Secrets of Quantum of Solace |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=5 April 2008 |url=http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/864/864542p1.html |accessdate=5 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410000608/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/864/864542p1.html |archivedate=10 April 2008 |df=dmy }} * [[Anatole Taubman]] as Elvis, Greene's second-in-command. Taubman wanted to make Elvis "as colourful, as edgy and as interesting as possible", with one of his suggestions being the [[bowl cut]].{{cite web|title=Anatole Taubman On Elvis|publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]]|date=7 November 2008|url=http://mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_qos_capsule_elvis.php3?t=qos&s=qos&id=02075|accessdate=9 November 2008}} Amalric and Taubman improvised a backstory for Elvis: he is Dominic's cousin and once lived on the streets before being inducted into Quantum. He called Elvis "a bit of a goofball. He thinks he's all that but he's not really. … He's not a comic guy. He definitely takes himself very serious, but maybe by his taking himself too serious he may become friendly."{{cite news | title = Elvis Rocks Bond's World | publisher = [[IGN]] | date = 16 May 2008 | url = http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/874/874700p1.html | accessdate = 16 May 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080521154755/http://uk.movies.ign.com/articles/874/874700p1.html | archivedate = 21 May 2008 | df = dmy-all }} * [[David Harbour]] as Gregg Beam, the CIA section chief for South America and a contact of Felix Leiter. * [[Joaquín Cosío]] as General Medrano, the exiled general whom Greene is helping to get back into power, in return for support of his organisation. He murdered Camille's entire family when she was a young girl. * [[Fernando Guillén Cuervo]] as Carlos, the Colonel of Bolivian Police, the chief of all police forces, and the contact of René Mathis in Bolivia. * [[Jesper Christensen]] as [[Mr. White (James Bond)|Mr. White]], whom Bond captured after he stole the money won at ''Casino Royale'' in Montenegro. * [[Rory Kinnear]] as [[Bill Tanner]], M's aide. * [[Paul Ritter (actor)|Paul Ritter]] as Guy Haines * [[Tim Pigott-Smith]] as the British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs]]. * [[Neil Jackson]] as Edmund Slate, a henchman who fights Bond in Haiti. * [[Simon Kassianides]] as Yusef, a member of Quantum who seduces female agents and manipulates them into giving away classified information. He is indirectly responsible for [[Vesper Lynd]]'s death. * [[Stana Katic]] as Corrine Veneau, a Canadian agent and Yusef's latest target. * Glenn Foster as Craig Mitchell, M's bodyguard and a double agent. * [[Oona Chaplin]] as Perla de las Dunas' receptionist, a woman saved by Camille Montes in one of the last sequences. * [[Lucrezia Lante della Rovere]] as Gemma, Mathis' girlfriend. * [[Elizabeth Arciniega]] as Mr. White's girlfriend. Marc Forster asked his friends and fellow directors [[Guillermo del Toro]] and [[Alfonso Cuarón]] to appear in cameos. Cuarón appears as a Bolivian helicopter pilot, while del Toro provides several other voices.{{cite news|title=Del Toro, Cuaron do voices in new Bond film|agency=Associated Press|date=23 October 2008|url=http://www.hitfix.com/articles/del-toro-cuaron-do-voices-in-new-bond-film|accessdate=23 October 2008}} ==Production== ===Development=== {{quote|If you remember in ''[[Chinatown (1974 film)|Chinatown]]'', if you control the water you control the whole development of the country. I think it's true. Right now it appears to be oil, but there's a lot of other resources that we don't think about too much but are all essential, and they're very limited and every country needs it. Because every country knows that raising the standard of living (and populations are getting bigger) is the way we're all going.|Michael G. Wilson on the plot.}} In July 2006, as ''Casino Royale'' entered post-production, Eon Productions announced that the next film would be based on an original idea by producer [[Michael G. Wilson]].{{cite news |author= Tatiana Siegel and Borys Kit |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002840141 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011120117/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002840141 |archivedate=11 October 2007|title= Roger Michell in Talks for Bond 22 |work= [[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date= 17 July 2006 |accessdate=17 July 2006}} It was decided beforehand the film would be a direct sequel, to exploit Bond's emotions following Vesper's death in the previous film.{{cite news | author = Liane Bonin | title = 10 Questions With: Daniel Craig | publisher = [[Moviefone]] | url = http://www.moviefone.com/insidemovies/2008/04/14/daniel-craig-interview-for-quantum-of-solace/ | accessdate = 11 April 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080613092700/http://www.moviefone.com/insidemovies/2008/04/14/daniel-craig-interview-for-quantum-of-solace/ | archivedate = 13 June 2008 | df = dmy-all }} Just as ''Casino Royale''{{'s}} theme was terrorism, the sequel focuses on environmentalism. The film was confirmed for a 2 May 2008 release date, with Craig reprising the lead role.{{cite news |author=[[Columbia Pictures]] |title=22nd James Bond Coming May 2, 2008! |publisher=[[Superhero Hype!]] |date=20 July 2006 |url=http://www.superherohype.com/news/jamesbondnews.php?id=4521 |accessdate=6 August 2007}} [[Roger Michell]], who directed Craig in ''[[Enduring Love (film)|Enduring Love]]'' and ''[[The Mother (film)|The Mother]]'', was in negotiations to direct, but opted out because there was no script.{{cite news |title=They call him Director No|work=[[The Times]]|date=4 July 2007|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/theatre/article1877785.ece|accessdate=27 January 2008 | location=London |first=Greg |last=Hurst}} Sony Entertainment vice-chairman Jeff Blake admitted a production schedule of 18 months was a very short window, and the release date was pushed back to late 2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=16308 |title=Bond 22 Targeting November 7, 2008 |publisher= [[Superhero Hype!]] |date=1 September 2006|accessdate=1 September 2006}} [[Neal Purvis and Robert Wade]] completed their draft of the script by April 2007,{{cite news|author=Michael Fleming|title='Barbarella' back in action|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=11 April 2007|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117962920.html |accessdate=6 August 2007}} and [[Paul Haggis]], who polished the ''Casino Royale'' script, began his rewrite the next month.{{cite news |title=Paul Haggis on board to work on Bond 22 script, but turns down directing role |publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]] |date=23 May 2007|url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/news/index.php?itemid=5040&catid=106 |accessdate=23 May 2007}} In June 2007, [[Marc Forster]] was confirmed as director.{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003600629 |title=Forster back in action with 'Bond 22' |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=20 June 2007 |accessdate=19 June 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183557/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003600629 |archivedate = 30 September 2007}} He was surprised that he was approached for the job, stating he was not a big Bond film fan through the years, and that he would not have accepted the project had he not seen ''Casino Royale'' prior to making his decision: he felt Bond had been humanised in that film, arguing since travelling the world had become less exotic since the series' advent, it made sense to focus more on Bond as a character. Born in Germany and raised in Switzerland, Forster was the first Bond director not to come from the [[British Commonwealth of Nations]], although he noted Bond's mother is Swiss, making him somewhat appropriate to handle the British icon.{{cite news |author=Terrence Rafferty |title=A License to Pursue the Inner Bond |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=9 December 2007|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/09/movies/09raff.html |accessdate=9 December 2007}} The director collaborated strongly with [[Barbara Broccoli]] and Michael G. Wilson, noting they only blocked two very expensive ideas he had. The director found ''Casino Royale''{{'}}s 144-minute running time too long, and wanted his follow-up to be "tight and fast … like a bullet."{{cite news|author=Alistair Harkness|title=A Quantum leap|work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=30 October 2008|url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/features/A-Quantum-leap.4643021.jp|accessdate=30 October 2008}} {{quote|Because Bond plays it real, I thought the political circumstances should be real too, even though Bond shouldn't be a political film. I thought the more political I make it, the more real it feels, not just with Bolivia and what's happening in Haiti, but with all these corporations like Shell and Chevron saying they're green because it's so fashionable to be green. During the Cold War, everything was very clear, the good guys and the bad guys. Today there's much overlapping of good and bad. It isn't as morally distinct, because we all have both elements in us.|Marc Forster on the political landscape of the film.}} Haggis, Forster and Wilson rewrote the story from scratch. Haggis said he completed his script two hours before the [[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike]] officially began. Forster noted a running theme in his films were emotionally repressed protagonists, and the theme of the picture would be Bond learning to trust after feeling betrayed by Vesper. Forster said he created the Camille character as a strong female counterpart to Bond rather than a casual love interest: she openly shows emotions similar to those which Bond experiences but is unable to express.{{cite news|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/911/911930p1.html|author=Jim Vejvoda|title=007 Responds to IGN Readers|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=22 September 2008|accessdate=22 September 2008}} Haggis located his draft's climax in the [[Swiss Alps]],{{cite news|author=Ian Nathan|title=Quantum's Leap|work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]|date=October 2008|pages=82–90}} but Forster wanted the action sequences to be based around the four [[classical element]]s of earth, water, air and fire.{{cite news|author=Anne Thompson|title='Solace' offers thinking person's 007|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=23 October 2008|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117994573.html |accessdate=1 November 2008|authorlink=Anne Thompson (film critic)}} The decision to homage [[Oddjob]]'s murder of Jill Masterson ([[Shirley Eaton]]) in ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' in Fields's death came about as Forster wanted to show oil had replaced gold as the most precious material.{{cite news|first=Ciaran |last=Carty|title='I felt there was pain in Bond'|work=[[Sunday Tribune]]|date=2 November 2008|url=http://tribune.maithu.com/article/2008/nov/02/i-felt-there-was-pain-in-bond/|accessdate=2 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206061930/http://www.tribune.ie/arts/films/article/2008/nov/02/i-felt-there-was-pain-in-bond/|archivedate=6 December 2008 }} The producers rejected Haggis's idea that Vesper Lynd had a child, because "Bond was an orphan … Once he finds the kid, Bond can't just leave the kid."{{cite news|author=Logan Hill|title=How James Bond Nearly Became a Father|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=3 November 2008|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2008/11/how_james_bond_nearly_became_a.html|accessdate=3 November 2008}} The [[Water supply and sanitation in Bolivia|water supply issue]] in Bolivia was the main theme of the film, with a story based on the [[Cochabamba]] [[2000 Cochabamba protests|Water Revolt]].[http://www.filmquarterly.org/2009/06/cinema-for-a-grand-new-game/ Cinema for a Grand New Game], ''[[Film Quarterly]]'' Michael G. Wilson decided on the film's title ''Quantum of Solace'' only "a few days" before its announcement on 24 January 2008.{{cite news |title=New Bond film title is confirmed |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=24 January 2008 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7206997.stm |accessdate=24 January 2008}} It was the name of a short story in [[Ian Fleming]]'s anthology ''[[For Your Eyes Only (short story collection)|For Your Eyes Only]]'' (1960). The film is related to the title in one of its thematic elements: "when the 'Quantum of Solace' drops to zero, humanity and consideration of one human for another is gone." Daniel Craig admitted, "I was unsure at first. Bond is looking for his quantum of solace and that's what he wants, he wants his closure. Ian Fleming says that if you don't have a quantum of solace in your relationship then the relationship is over. It's that spark of niceness in a relationship that if you don't have you might as well give up." He said that "Bond doesn't have that because his girlfriend [Vesper Lynd] has been killed,"{{cite news |title=Daniel: the title is meant to confuse |work=[[Press and Journal (Scotland)|Press and Journal]] |date=24 January 2008}} and therefore, "[Bond is] looking for revenge … to make himself happy with the world again." Afterwards, Quantum was made the name of the organisation introduced in ''Casino Royale''. Craig noted the letter Q itself looks rather odd. Near the end of the film, the Camille Montes character and Bond have a discussion about their individual quests to avenge the deaths of their loved ones. Montes asks Bond to "let me know what it feels like" when he succeeds, the implication of the title being that it will be a small amount of solace compared to his despair. Bond's lack of emotion when he does exact revenge shows this to be the case. According to a December 2011 interview with Craig, "We had the bare bones of a script and then there was a writers' strike and there was nothing we could do. We couldn't employ a writer to finish it. I say to myself, 'Never again', but who knows? There was me trying to rewrite scenes—and a writer I am not."{{cite web|last=Goldberg|first=Matt|title=Daniel Craig Talks about the Script Problems on QUANTUM OF SOLACE; Says Why He's Encouraged for SKYFALL|url=http://collider.com/daniel-craig-quantum-of-solace-script-problems/130951/|publisher=Collider|accessdate=29 August 2012|date=7 December 2011}} He said that he and Forster "were the ones allowed to do it. The rules were that you couldn't employ anyone as a writer, but the actor and director could work on scenes together. We were stuffed. We got away with it, but only just. It was never meant to be as much of a sequel as it was, but it ended up being a sequel, starting where the last one finished." During filming, after the strike ended, Forster read a [[spec script]] by Joshua Zetumer, which he liked, and hired him to reshape scenes for the later parts of the shoot, which the director was still unsatisfied with.{{cite news|title=A James Bond Set Visit and Seven Exclusive Quantum of Solace Images! |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |date=4 April 2008 |url=http://uk.rottentomatoes.com/m/quantum_of_solace/news/1719930/a_james_bond_set_visit_and_seven_exclusive_quantum_of_solace_images |accessdate=5 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005195337/http://uk.rottentomatoes.com/m/quantum_of_solace/news/1719930/a_james_bond_set_visit_and_seven_exclusive_quantum_of_solace_images |archivedate= 5 October 2008 |df= }} Forster had the actors rehearse their scenes, as he liked to film scenes continually.{{cite news | author = Karl Rozemeyer | title = Mathieu Amalric on Being the 'Bond 22' Villain | work = [[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]] | date = 18 March 2008 | url = http://www.premiere.com/features/4455/mathieu-amalric-on-being-the-bond-22-villain.html | accessdate=19 March 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321210654/http://www.premiere.com/features/4455/mathieu-amalric-on-being-the-bond-22-villain.html|archivedate=21 March 2008}} Zetumer rewrote dialogue depending on the actors' ideas each day. ===Filming=== [[File:Ingresso della Forra a Tremosine.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''Strada delle Forre'' in [[Tremosine]] ([[Italy]]) where the movie begins.]] ''Quantum of Solace'' was shot in six countries.{{cite news|author=Randee Dawn|title='Quantum' is Marc Forster's 007 art film|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=11 November 2008|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3ie9098baec9eb95cd02a01aebbd96a968|accessdate=13 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081113031127/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3ie9098baec9eb95cd02a01aebbd96a968|archivedate=13 November 2008}} [[Second unit]] filming began in Italy at the [[Palio di Siena]] horse race on 16 August 2007,{{cite news|author=Richard Owen|title=Bond has activists on his tail over new film's 'brutal' horse race finale|work=[[The Times]]|date=13 August 2007|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article2246486.ece|accessdate=13 August 2007 | location=London}} although at that point Forster was unsure how it would fit into the film. Some scenes were filmed also in [[Maratea]] and [[Craco]], two small distinctive towns in [[Basilicata]] in southern Italy.{{cite news|publisher=imdb.com|title=Filming locations for Quantum of Solace|date=11 November 2008|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0830515/locations|accessdate=2 June 2009}} Other places used for location shooting were [[Madrid]] in August 2007;{{cite news |title=Bond 22 filming takes place in Madrid, Spain during last week of August|publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]] |date=31 August 2007|url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/news/index.php?itemid=5327 |accessdate=25 March 2008}} [[Baja California]], Mexico in early 2008, for shots of the aerial battle;{{cite news|title=Newswrap No. 2 video |publisher=[[ReelzChannel]] |date=20 March 2008 |url=http://www.reelzchannel.com/movie/233698/quantum-of-solace?clipid=32934 |accessdate=20 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322172830/http://www.reelzchannel.com/movie/233698/quantum-of-solace?clipid=32934 |archivedate=22 March 2008 |df= }}{{cite news|author=David Allen|title=A bond with Chino|publisher=[[Los Angeles Newspaper Group]]|date=28 February 2008|url=http://www.dailybulletin.com/ci_8399719|accessdate=2 March 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603232620/http://www.dailybulletin.com/ci_8399719|archivedate=3 June 2008 }} [[Malcesine]], [[Limone sul Garda]] and [[Tremosine]] in Italy during March,{{cite news | title = Production Diary (16) | publisher= [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 17 March 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary16.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=20 March 2008}} and at [[Talamone]] during the end of April.{{cite news | title = Production Diary (19) | publisher= [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 27 March 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary19.php3?t=&s= | accessdate=28 March 2008}} The main unit began on 3 January 2008 at [[Pinewood Studios]]. The [[007 Stage]] was used for the fight in the art gallery,{{cite news |author=Mark Brown|title=Everything changes but Bond |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=24 January 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jan/24/features|accessdate=24 January 2008 | location=London}} and an MI6 safehouse hidden within the city's [[cistern]]s,{{cite news |author=Tim Marsters |title=Behind the scenes on the Bond set |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=25 January 2008|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7208410.stm |accessdate=25 January 2008}} while other stages housed Bond's Bolivian hotel suite, and the MI6 headquarters. Interior and exterior airport scenes were filmed at [[Farnborough Airfield]] and the snowy closing scenes were filmed at the Bruneval Barracks in [[Aldershot]].{{cite news|url=http://www.gethampshire.co.uk/news/s/2038353_barracks_and_airport_provide_location_for_bond_film|title = Barracks and airport provide location for Bond film|accessdate=18 November 2008|author=Rebecca Connop Price|date=30 October 2008|publisher=Get Hampshire|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110913050519/http://www.gethampshire.co.uk/news/s/2038353_barracks_and_airport_provide_location_for_bond_film|archivedate=13 September 2011}} Shooting in [[Panama City]] began on 7 February 2008 at [[Howard Air Force Base]]. The country doubled for Haiti and Bolivia, with the National Institute of Culture of Panama standing in for a hotel in the latter country. A sequence requiring several hundred [[extra (actor)|extras]] was also shot at nearby [[Colón, Panama|Colón]].{{cite news | title = Production Diary (11) | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 9 February 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary11.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=9 February 2008}} Shooting in Panama was also carried out at [[Fort Sherman]], a former US military base on the Colón coast. Forster was disappointed he could only shoot the boat chase in that harbour, as he had a more spectacular vision for the scene.{{cite news|author=Edward Douglas|title=Marc Forster Finds His Quantum of Solace|publisher=ComingSoon.net|date=10 November 2008|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=50314|accessdate=10 November 2008}} Officials in the country worked with the locals to "minimise inconvenience" for the cast and crew, and in return hoped the city's exposure in the film would increase tourism.{{cite news | title = Production Diary (9) | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 2 February 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary09.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=8 February 2008}} The crew was going to move to [[Cusco]], Peru for ten days of filming on 2 March, but the location was cancelled for budget reasons. Twelve days of filming in Chile began on 24 March at [[Antofagasta]]. There was shooting in [[Cobija, Chile|Cobija]], the [[Paranal Observatory]], and other locations in the [[Atacama Desert]].{{cite news | title = Production Diary (17) | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 19 March 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary17.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=20 March 2008}} Forster chose the desert and the observatory's [[ESO Hotel]] to represent Bond's rigid emotions, and being on the verge of committing a vengeful act as he confronts Greene in the film's climax.{{cite news | title = Seeking Solace on the Bond set |work=[[USA Today]] | date = 3 April 2008 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/flash.htm?gid=459 | accessdate=4 April 2008}} [[File:Paranal camp.jpg|thumb|left|Marc Forster chose the [[Atacama Desert]] to represent Bond's vengefulness in the climax.|alt=A scientific facility in a desert]] During filming in [[Sierra Gorda, Chile]], the local mayor, Carlos Lopez, staged a protest because he was angry at the filmmakers' portrayal of the [[Antofagasta Region]] as part of Bolivia. He was arrested, detained briefly, and put on trial two days later. Eon dismissed his claim that they needed his permission to film in the area.{{cite news | author = Simon Gardner | title = James Bond has new nemesis: irate Chilean mayor | agency=Reuters | date = 2 April 2008 | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUKN0237294620080402 | accessdate=13 September 2008}}{{cite news | title = 'Mayor' protests on Chile 007 set |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] | date = 2 April 2008 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7326582.stm | accessdate=3 April 2008}} Michael G. Wilson explained that Bolivia was appropriate to the plot, because of the country's history of water problems,{{cite news |author=Anthony Breznican |title=James Bond series takes a 'Quantum' leap |work=USA Today |date=4 April 2008|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2008-04-03-bond-quantum_N.htm |accessdate=4 April 2008}} and was surprised the two countries disliked each other a century after the [[War of the Pacific]].{{cite news | title = Production Diary (22) | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 7 April 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary22.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=10 April 2008}} In a poll by Chilean daily newspaper ''[[La Segunda]]'', 75% of its readers disagreed with Lopez's actions, due to the negative image of Chile they felt it presented, and the controversy's potential to put off productions looking to film in the country in the future.{{cite news | title = ¿Apoya Ud. las protestas del alcalde de Sierra Gorda por la filmación de James Bond en su comuna? | work = [[La Segunda]] | date = 2 March 2008 | url = http://www.lasegunda.com/edicionOnline/interaccion/encuestas/resultado.asp?idencuesta=2512&idclasificacion=3&fg= | archive-url = https://archive.is/20080405174454/http://www.lasegunda.com/edicionOnline/interaccion/encuestas/resultado.asp?idencuesta=2512&idclasificacion=3&fg= | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 5 April 2008 | language=Spanish | accessdate=2 April 2008}} From 4–12 April the main unit shot on Sienese rooftops. Shooting on the real rooftops turned out to be less expensive than building them at Pinewood. The next four weeks were scheduled for filming the car chase at [[Lake Garda]] and [[Carrara]]. On 19 April, an [[Aston Martin]] employee driving a [[Aston Martin DBS V12|DBS]] to the set crashed into the lake. He survived, and was fined £400 for reckless driving.{{cite news | author = Nick Pisa | title = Driver of James Bond's Aston Martin cheated death in dramatic crash |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 22 April 2008}} Another accident occurred on 21 April, and two days later, two stuntmen were seriously injured, with one, Greek stuntman Aris Comninos, having to be put in intensive care. Filming of the scenes was temporarily halted so that Italian police could investigate the causes of the accidents.{{cite news | author = Paul Bompard | title = James Bond production halted amid fears of a curse |work=[[The Times]] | date = 24 April 2008 | url =http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article3810782.ece | accessdate=24 April 2008 | location=London}} Stunt co-ordinator Gary Powell said the accidents were a testament to the realism of the action. Rumours of a "curse" spread among tabloid media, something which deeply offended Craig, who disliked that they compared Comninos' accident to something like his minor finger injury later on the shoot (also part of the "curse"). Comninos recovered safely from his injury. For the role Craig trained to be less bulky than in ''Casino Royale'' and told ''[[Men's Fitness]]'' magazine "In fact, I was much fitter for this film compared to ''Casino Royale''—I really had to be—and I was running a hell of a lot more in training, just so I could do these scenes, whereas last time I spent far more time pumping heavy weights to bulk up so I could look big."{{Cite web|url=https://mattpomroy.com/2008/12/01/quantum-physique/|title=Quantum Physique|date=2008-12-01|website=Matt Pomroy|access-date=2017-06-07}} Filming took place at the [[Bregenzer Festspiele|floating opera stage]] at [[Bregenz]], Austria, from 28 April – 9 May 2008. The sequence in which Bond stalks the villains during a performance of ''[[Tosca]]'' required 1,500 extras.{{cite news | title = Production Diary (10) | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 8 February 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary10.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=9 February 2008}} The production used a large model of an eye, which Forster felt fitted in the Bond style, and the opera itself has parallels to the film.{{cite news|title='Quantum of Solace' set visit: filming in Austria; Craig's next Bond moves; 007's new foes; rumors laid to rest|publisher=[[MSN]]|date=8 May 2008|url=http://movies.msn.com/movies/hitlist/05-13-08|accessdate=16 May 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010045516/http://movies.msn.com/movies/hitlist/05-13-08/|archivedate=10 October 2009}} A short driving sequence was filmed at the nearby [[Feldkirch, Vorarlberg]].{{cite news |title=Production Diary (1) |publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]] |date=3 January 2008|url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary01.php3?t=&s=articles |accessdate=8 January 2008}} The crew returned to Italy from 13–17 May to shoot a (planned) car crash at the marble quarry in Carrara,{{cite news | title = Production Diary (32) | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 16 May 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary32.php3?t=qos&s=qos | accessdate=16 May 2008}} and a recreation of the Palio di Siena at the [[Piazza del Campo]] in Siena. 1,000 extras were hired for a scene where Bond emerges from the ''Fonte Gaia''. Originally, he would have emerged from the city's cisterns at [[Siena Cathedral]], but this was thought disrespectful. By June the crew returned to Pinewood for four weeks, where new sets (including the interior of the hotel in the climax) were built. The [[wrap (filmmaking)|wrap]] party was held on 21 June.{{cite news | title = 'Quantum of Solace' wrap party held on Saturday night, David Arnold confirms | publisher = [[MI6-HQ.com]] | date = 22 June 2008 | url = http://www.mi6-hq.com/news/index.php?itemid=6394 | accessdate=22 June 2008}} ===Design=== Production designer [[Peter Lamont]], a crew member on 18 previous Bond films, retired after ''Casino Royale''.{{cite news |title=Peter Lamont bows out from Bond 22, Dennis Gassner to be Production Designer |publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]] |date=23 July 2007|url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/news/index.php?itemid=5206 |accessdate=23 July 2007}} Forster hired [[Dennis Gassner]] in his stead, having admired his work on ''[[The Truman Show]]'' and the films of the [[Coen brothers]].{{cite web|url=http://mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_qos_capsule_forster.php3?t=qos&s=qos&id=02080|title=Marc Forster on directing 007|publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]]|date=11 November 2008|accessdate=13 November 2008}} Craig said the film would have "a touch of [[Ken Adam]],"{{cite news |author=Olly Richards |title=Daniel Craig Talks Quantum of Solace |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |date=24 January 2008 |url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=21855 |accessdate=24 January 2008}} while Michael G. Wilson also called Gassner's designs "a [[postmodern]] look at [[modernism]]."{{cite news|title=Quantum of Solace – Production Diary (7)|publisher=[[MI6-HQ.com]]|date=26 January 2008|url=http://www.mi6-hq.com/sections/articles/bond_22_prod_diary07.php3?t=&s=|accessdate=26 January 2008}} Forster said he felt the early Bond films' design "were ahead of their time," and enjoyed the clashing of an older style with his own because it created a unique look unto itself. Gassner wanted his sets to emphasise Craig's "great angular, textured face and wonderful blue eyes," and totally redesigned the MI6 headquarters because he felt Judi Dench "was a bit tired in the last film, so I thought, let's bring her into a new world."{{cite news|title=James Bond: licence to redesign|work=[[Maclean's]]|date=17 November 2008|url=http://blog.macleans.ca/2008/11/17/james-bond-licence-to-redesign/|accessdate=18 November 2008}} Louise Frogley replaced [[Lindy Hemming]] as [[costume design]]er, though Hemming remained as supervisor. Hemming hired [[Brioni (fashion)|Brioni]] for Bond's suits since her tenure on the series began with 1995's ''[[GoldenEye]]'', but Lindsay Pugh, another supervisor, explained their suits were "too relaxed." [[Tom Ford]] was hired to tailor "sharper" suits for Craig. Pugh said the costumes aimed towards the 1960s feel, especially for Bond and Fields. [[Prada]] provided the dresses for both Bond girls. [[Jasper Conran]] designed Camille's ginger bandeau, bronze skirt and gold fish necklace,{{cite web|url=http://www.jasperconran.com/collections/womenswear/archive/james-bond,116,ART.html |title=Jasper Conran Spring Summer 2008 Collection |publisher=Jasperconran.com |accessdate=12 September 2010}} while [[Chrome Hearts]] designed gothic jewellery for Amalric's character, which the actor liked enough to keep after filming.{{cite news|author=Jessica Fellowes|title=James Bond week: 007 and his girls are back with a crisp new look|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=22 October 2008|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG3365681/James-Bond-week-007-and-his-girls-are-back-with-a-crisp-new-look.html|accessdate=25 October 2008 | location=London}} Sophie Harley, who created [[Vesper Lynd]]'s earrings and Algerian loveknot necklace in ''Casino Royale'', was called upon to create another version of the necklace.{{cite news|author=Jessica Fellowes|title=Necklace with a starring role|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=22 October 2008|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/news-features/TMG3365680/Necklace-with-a-starring-role.html|accessdate=25 October 2008 | location=London}} The film returns to the traditional [[James Bond gun barrel sequence|gun barrel opening shot]], which was altered into part of the story for ''Casino Royale'' where it was moved to the beginning of the title sequence. In this film the gun barrel sequence was moved to the end of the movie, which Wilson explained was done for a surprise,{{cite news|author=Mark Caro|title=15 James Bond facts you need to know|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=9 November 2008|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-11-09/news/0811070249_1_casino-royale-daniel-craig-olga-kurylenko|accessdate=8 November 2008}} and to signify the conclusion of the story begun in the previous film. The opening credits sequence was created by [[MK12]]. Having worked on Forster's ''[[Stranger than Fiction (2006 film)|Stranger than Fiction]]'' and ''[[The Kite Runner (film)|The Kite Runner]]'', MK12 spontaneously began developing the sequence early on in production, and had a good idea of its appearance which meant it did not have to be redone when the [[#Music|title singer]] was changed. MK12 selected various twilight colours to represent Bond's mood and focused on a dot motif based on the gunbarrel shot. MK12 also worked on scenes with [[graphical user interface]], including the electronic table MI6 use,{{cite news|url=http://vfxworld.com/index.php?atype=articles&id=3881 |author=Bill Desowitz |title=MK12 Has a Blast with Quantum Main Titles |publisher=VFXWorld |date=16 January 2009 |accessdate=26 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607045355/http://vfxworld.com/index.php?atype=articles&id=3881 |archivedate= 7 June 2009 |df= }} and the [[Port-au-Prince]], Haiti title cards.{{cite news|author=Yves Peters|title=MK12 Create Custom Type for Quantum of Solace Title Sequence|publisher=[[FontShop]]|date=19 December 2008|url=http://fontfeed.com/archives/mk12-quantum-of-solace-title-sequence/|accessdate=22 December 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222234148/http://fontfeed.com/archives/mk12-quantum-of-solace-title-sequence/|archivedate=22 December 2008|df=dmy-all}} ===Effects=== [[File:AstonMartinDBSCC08.jpg|thumb|right|[[Aston Martin DBS V12]] on display at the 2008 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]]|alt=A black car in an exhibition.]] ''Quantum of Solace'' was the last in [[Ford Motor Company|Ford Motor]]'s three-film deal that began with 2002's ''[[Die Another Day]]''. Although Ford sold over 90% of the [[Aston Martin]] company in 2007, the [[Aston Martin DBS V12]] returned for the film's car chase around Lake Garda;{{cite news |title=Aston Martin DBS to star in new James Bond film |publisher=[[Aston Martin]] |year=2007 |url=http://www.astonmartin.com/thecompany/news?a=14d34f22-1324-4ca5-acbb-764f80c7d7f2 |accessdate=11 December 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523032827/http://www.astonmartin.com/thecompany/news?a=14d34f22-1324-4ca5-acbb-764f80c7d7f2|archivedate=23 May 2009}} [[Dan Bradley]] was hired as [[second unit]] director because of his work on the second and third [[Bourne (film series)|''Bourne'' films]], so the film would continue the gritty action style begun in ''Casino Royale''.{{cite news |author=Borys Kit |title=Bradley tapped to aid Bond stunts |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=4 September 2007 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3i61cdc71247ef46a7ec4bddbba9463397 |accessdate=10 January 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070913085544/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3i61cdc71247ef46a7ec4bddbba9463397 |archivedate = 13 September 2007}} He had intended to use [[Ford GT]]s for the opening chase,{{cite web|title=Dan Bradley interview |publisher=Bourne Stunt Simulator |url=http://www.bournestuntsimulator.com/danbradley/ |accessdate=16 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080128143935/http://www.bournestuntsimulator.com/danbradley/ |archivedate=28 January 2008 |df= }} but it was replaced by the [[Alfa Romeo 159]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1902288/James-Bond-filming-suspended-after-third-accident-leaves-stuntman-in-coma.html|title=James Bond filming suspended after third accident leaves stuntman in coma|accessdate=28 April 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 April 2008 | location=London | first=Malcolm | last=Moore}} After location filming in Italy, further close-ups of Craig, the cars and the truck were shot at Pinewood against a blue screen.{{cite news|author=Bill Desowitz|title=A Quantum of VFX for James Bond|publisher=VFX World|date=3 December 2008|url=http://vfxworld.com/?atype=articles&id=3844&page=1#|accessdate=4 December 2008}} Originally three Alfa Romeos were in the sequence: but Forster felt the scene was running too long and re-edited the scene so it only looked like two Alfas were chasing Bond. Six Aston Martins were destroyed during filming, and one of them was purchased by a fan. Fourteen cameras were used to film the [[Palio di Siena]] footage, which was later edited into the main sequence. Aerial shots using helicopters were banned, and the crew were also forbidden from showing any violence "involving either people or animals." To shoot the foot chase in [[Siena]] in April 2008 four camera cranes were built in the town, and a [[Skycam|cable camera]] was also used. [[Framestore]] worked on the Siena chase, duplicating the 1,000 extras during principal photography to match shots of the 40,000-strong audience at the real Palio, removing wires that held Craig and the stuntmen in the rooftop segment of the chase, and digital expansion of the floor and skylight in the art gallery Bond and Mitchell fall into. The art gallery fight was intended to be simple, but during filming Craig's stunt double accidentally fell from the construction scaffolding. Forster preferred the idea of Bond hanging from ropes reaching for his gun to kill Mitchell, rather than having both men run out of the building to continue their chase as specified in the script, and the number of effects shots increased. To film the aerial dogfight, a "Snakehead" camera was built and placed on the nose and tail of a [[Piper Aerostar]] 700. [[SolidWorks]], who provided the software used to design the camera, stated "pilots for the first time can fly as aggressively as they dare without sacrificing the drama of the shot." The camera could turn 360 degrees and was shaped like a [[periscope]].{{cite news | author = Chris Reidy | title = "Snakehead" films James Bond dogfight footage |work=[[The Boston Globe]] | date = 12 May 2008 | url = http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2008/05/_the_concord_of.html | accessdate=12 May 2008}} The crew also mounted SpaceCams on helicopters, and placed cameras with 1600mm lenses underground, to cover the action. Forster wanted to film the plane fight as a homage to [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s ''[[North by Northwest]]'', and chose planes like the [[Douglas DC-3]] to suit that.{{cite news|title=Capone talks with James Bond himself, Daniel Craig, and Quantum of Solace director Marc Forster in London!!!|publisher=[[Ain't It Cool News]]|date=21 September 2008|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/38427|accessdate=22 September 2008}}{{cite news|title=For Your Eyes Only: RT in Austria with James Bond |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |date=9 May 2008 |url=http://uk.rottentomatoes.com/m/quantum_of_solace/news/1727255/2/for_your_eyes_only_rt_in_austria_with_james_bond |accessdate=16 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208092012/http://uk.rottentomatoes.com/m/quantum_of_solace/news/1727255/2/for_your_eyes_only_rt_in_austria_with_james_bond |archivedate= 8 December 2008 |df= }} The [[free-fall]] scene involved its own set of challenges; Craig disliked the idea of "being hung by wires and blown by a large fan in front of a green screen"{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}, but actual [[sky diving]] coverage has serious drawbacks. It's not only difficult, dangerous and time-consuming, but nearly always results in problematic head-replacements for close-ups{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}. Stunt co-ordinator Gary Powell and VFX Designer [[Kevin Tod Haug]] presented the idea of filming the scene in a large [[vertical wind tunnel]] in [[Bedford]] to do this sequence as practically as possible{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}. While a great solution for the actors' performances, the technique presented enormous VFX challenges: relighting shots captured in a tall white tube to match the sky over the Bolivian desert; and the impossibility of filming medium to wide shots of the actors. An array of eight [[Dalsa Origin]] cameras (supported by seven HD cameras and a 35mm hand-held camera, all running in sync) was used to create a [[virtual camera]] with which to shoot the actors floating in the simulator. [[Ged Wright]] and his team at [[Double Negative (VFX)|Double Negative]] developed a method to use the data from these cameras that allowed these real performances to be placed in a synthetic environment as seen by a synthetic camera. During the shooting in the wind tunnel Craig and Kurylenko wore wind-resistant contact lenses that enabled them to open their eyes as they fell. For safety and comfort, they only shot for 30 seconds at a time.{{cite news|url=http://movieblog.ugo.com/index.php/movieblog/more/your_quantum_of_solace_questions_answered/ |title=Your Quantum of Solace Questions Answered! |publisher=[[UGO Networks]] |date=21 September 2008 |accessdate=22 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924230111/http://movieblog.ugo.com/index.php/movieblog/more/your_quantum_of_solace_questions_answered/ |archivedate=24 September 2008 |df= }} Forster wished he had had more time to work on the free-fall scene. The [[Moving Picture Company]] created the climactic hotel sequence.
